results.content:
Just over half way through but I find this course to be a bit disappointing. The instructor seems like a really nice person, but PHP code that you write seems to be really unplanned and messy and the instructor goes off on random tangents rather than sticking to the purpose of the code. Some of the videos could be edited down to be half the length, or sections could be combined because what they cover is too small.

I'll update this review if I think it gets better as the course goes on, but I am a bit disappointed with this course compared to all the other Udemy courses I have bought.

Sorry Edwin. I'm glad others like it though and I am getting some use out of it, I just think it could be reworked to be much sharper.

EDIT:
I am further through the course and I have to admit that my confidence with PHP is greatly improved. I still think that the course could do with editing and maybe re-recording some sections but it is teaching me the basics of PHP via the CMS project which is quite interesting.

results.content: I'm a graphics student in The Netherlands. We mainly learn about HTML and CSS but the websites we're making aren't really dynamic. It was all static and in my opinion "boring". Not the cool stuff you see on the web: No login function, no comment sections. We learned how to design them, but they didn't work. And hey, we want them to work right? So I started trying to make them work on my own, I already had a basic understanding of PHP so it wouldn't be that difficult.. I thought. As soon as I had one thing working, the other thing wouldn't work anymore and errors came all over my screen. I needed help, seriously. So I went to google, and found a couple websites where people explained what went wrong and how to do it right. But I still didn't understand really what I was doing and the code looked real messy, changing one thing would destroy my whole website. I had to understand what I was doing, changing plans, so I went to codecademy and tried to learn PHP on there. Determined and optimistic I started the free course, but all the things we learned; well it wasn't practically and it had no real life examples. I had no clue where to go next, ready to give up. I asked myself if I maybe just had to stay to design and just should hand over my "boring" websites to expensive webdevelopers who know what they're doing and maybe I was just not bright enough to understand PHP. But then I realized, as a baby we didn't know how to walk. We had to learn it by trial and error, standing up and falling down just to stand up again. Nobody thought we "weren't bright enough” or that we should buy expensive wheelchairs. And it's the same with PHP and all other things we want to learn, we just have to find the right teacher, the right course. So I went back to google and started searching on PHP courses, to finally come out at this PHP course. For a good discount I could try it, and if it didn't live up to my expectations I could get my money back. It sounded great and so I wen't on and tried the course. I'm now at the middle of the course, still a lot to learn but I really feel like I'm finally understanding what I'm doing and what I learn is immediately usable in real life. And if I still don’t understand something, I can go to the community and we can help each other out. Thank you Edwin and of course the community for the amazing opportunities the course is giving me!

results.content:
The lecture style is scatterbrained to the extreme.
Watching the instructor constantly fix typos and bearing with him while he ad-libs his videos quickly becomes tedious. He keeps selecting / scrolling / resizing windows randomly while he talks so you're left feeling like an ADD monkey after watching 5 minutes of it.
Also, his explanations of basic programming concepts are terrible - he says the weirdest things that don't even make sense, like "functions are more powerful than variables." His explanation of PHP-specific things like superglobals are basically incomprehensible.

results.content:
I've been greatly enjoying Edwin's PHP course!

Pros:
- Instruction is presented in almost a conversational way that makes it easy to understand and fun to go along with.
- The instructor starts with the absolute basics and walks you through the setup and any basic coding principles you need to know to be successful.
- The course provides ample opportunities to practice your knowledge. This isn't just a "monkey see, monkey do" course like many others. You're expected to learn and apply your knowledge.
- Quizzes pop up to also test your knowledge. Some of the questions force you to think of things that haven't exactly been covered, which is great for forcing you to expand the concepts.

Cons:
- On rare occasion, some code is presented in a way that I wouldn't consider "best practice." For instance, using both double and single quotes in the same file with no seemingly rhyme or reason for the jumps between the two. This is a small complaint because the code still works in PHP but more junior developers might be confused by this or could pick it up as a bad habit when moving to a different programming language. The same could be said about indention practices. 

Indifferent:
- For experienced programmers, this might be too slow of a course. I believe everything the instructor says has a value and no words are wasted, but if you're someone who already knows coding fundementals then you might find this course to drag in the beginning.

Overall, I give this course a 5. The instructor is excellent at presenting the material, the material goes in-depth without being long-winded, and you'll be coding with PHP in no time!

results.content:
The course is comprehensive, it really is. I have spent countless hours and still only reached about 20%. Edwin covers a lot of topics in the course and new material is added continuously. He is also dedicated and somewhat inspirational in his lecturing.

What I don't like is that even though the course covers the basics of PHP Edwin quite often talks about complex topics as if the student was already an expert on the matter. 
I have studied some programming some years ago so I recognize a lot of the concepts of PHP and I often find myself thinking that a lot of things could have been explained way better for the student. Instead I'm more confused after a lecture than before it and sometimes I have to look up things on other sites in order to fully understand them.

results.content:
I feel at an early stage, that too much detail is already being provided in the wrong areas. Lots of detail about things such as why comments are useful, something that while true, is not actually necessary and could be compacted into a short tip rather than a long explanation, whereas other areas such as the download of the software needed to actually put the work into practice was pre-downloaded before the video was recorded, so he was blindly telling you "there should be a button somewhere around here" rather than actually step by step walking you through a confusing process. This happened in other areas too, and while usually self explanatory (a button saying "install" etc) it would have been a good idea to walk through these steps with students.

Further to this, the audio is appalling. The sound is tinny and distant, meaning when you turn the volume all the way up the sound is harsh on your ears and means you struggle to hear what the tutor is saying anyway.

This is an early review and will be updated as I go along, but these are things that I'm sure will remain a constant throughout.

results.content:
So overall, this course is amazing.  Edwin takes you step by step through learning PHP and then building a website that fully incorporates PHP.  

Edwin is a great teacher that codes live while he lectures.  His videos are typically no longer than 10 minutes so it is easy to structure out a self taught study pace.  

Because he is coding live, Edwin tends to make small typos, errors, or coding mistakes during the lecture.  This is normal for any programmer and Edwin will walk you through the process of debugging the problem.  I learned as much from the mistakes as I did the lectures.  

My only critique (and I am nitpicking here) was his section on the PHP/mysql security practices and lectures.  At the end of the course, I do not feel that end program is 100% ready to go live on the internet.  It would take an "extra" few steps from a security standpoint.  

Now I will admit that a full on class on security may be out of the scope of the course, but I think a few extra lectures could have been spent on additional precautions, steps and best practices on security.  

Edwin does touch on security and prevention of malicious events, but I felt more should have been done.  

Overall, I highly, highly, highly recommend this course.  It is a must for anyone who is serious about web development.

results.content: Edwin seems like a great guy who really wants to teach his students, he has a great personality and has a great teaching style. He does a pretty good job of explaining the concepts of what he is teaching. The biggest fault I found with the course is that he does not provide the code at the end of each lecture showing the completed code for the material covered in the lecture. Very difficult to always get the code correct from watching the video. If you discover your site not working properly and not sure when the error happened, there is no way to recover from the mistake. Not having the code at the end of each lecture generates so many questions from students trying to get help correcting their code that it is virtually impossible for Edwin to answer every question, so you're left hanging unless one of the other students can help you out. If the code was provided at the end of each lecture, 80% of the questions would be eliminated.

results.content:
Half way..
I'm an enthusiastic amateur and 68 years young.  I've dabbled in all sorts of web related subjects, WordPress, HTML, css and a lot more.  After looking at a lot of online courses I bought this one when it was on offer at a ridiculously low price. Although pitched at beginners I'm half way through and have learned a lot and becoming more confident with some of the more common tasks that php performs.  I'm not sure I like the method of taking a functional theme and removing large sections, why not build it from the ground up using basic HTML and css - and layer on the php to give the functionality?
I think subscribers should realise that at the end of this course they will not be  php programmers but will have a better understanding of the language and be able to look at more advanced course with a bit more confidence.  Edwin's style is quite acceptable but in some lectures he cuts/pastes and refactors at a rate that is sometime hard to follow.  As I say, I'm half way through and my approach is now different from the beginning when all I did was watch the lecture then rewind and type the code provided.  Now I listen to the beginning of the lecture and see if I can do what is asked on my own.  If I can't get it to work,  I then watch the lecture.
Finishing line...
Now that I have completed the course, I haven't  really changed the above opinion.  Useful foundation course but the only thing now is to learn more! Don't think I'm a programmer because I'm not - this is just the beginning.  I'll have a rest now and maybe look at jQuery.  One final point, I think it would be useful if Edwin set little projects (aside form the CMS we work on)...like use php to capitilise every second letter of a word or produce 5 unique random numbers...things like that.
Anyway, I've sort of enjoyed it (hard at times) but feel a bit inadequate because I know I'm at the bottom of the food chain when it comes to php programming.
Good luck to all students talking this course

+) Constant updates, new lectures, new features, this way the course will never get expired / deprecated
+) Most importantly: a lot of help from the CodingFaculty team (including Edwin), always answering all the questions with patience and kind help! For me, this is the most important: that I always have someone I can turn to in case I need help / assistance... :)
-) The videos could be a little bit better organized, so it would be easier for the students to follow the exact same code(!) Edwin has.

Thank you guys! You are an amazing team!!!! :-)

results.content: Teacher was very enthusiastic and good however I found a little too many things to be off for me to love this course. I had to watch videos at 1.5x speed just for it to be normal, which is okay but a ton of time was spent finding and fixing user errors. I get that it is normal to make mistakes and beginners will make them too but i found way too much time spent doing this. Another major annoyance to me was the user of white space. It doesn't matter to the compiler but it was very hard to see where Edwin was inserting things because of the lack of indentation and overuse of blank lines. Things weren't indented to align with the html code and it just made me lose my place a lot. If it wasn't for the errors and white space this course would get a 4.5/5 from me

results.content:
It doesn't matter that PHP is now up to version 8 and version 5 is pretty much dead. I bought this course in 2017 and it is only just now I thought I must devote a week to finishing this, rather than simply copying and pasting the entire code.

At that time I was in a rush to build something.

The one thing I appreciate about having to go backwards in order to move forward is the actual process of programming and understanding the mechanics of why I am doing what I am doing. Edwin pretty much breaks it all down so you can understand it. It has taken me about five years just to get through PHP 4 and 5 only to find the goalposts have shifted once more so I wanted to go back to the basics in order to get better at it.

I think I do want to re-learn JavaScript and OOP with Edwin because he has a unique way of breaking things down. If you are looking for someone who comes across as a one-dimensional professional with no personality, this guy is not it. He is very much human. I also like that the project is being updated with new features.

My confidence has increased to the point where I can transfer what I have learnt to building apps using native PHP or a framework. There is a good foundation to be had here.

I will also be returning to complete the additional features.

Thanks, Edwin!

results.content:
MUST Buy if you starting PHP journey.

Edy keeps you engaged in whats he talking about, he also did not made it super clean and nifty , he shows you real world behavior behind monitor of coder. You will make mistakes, you will try to figure it out yourself, or with help of others, you will search for better solutions online or answers on some blogs somewhere. This is the real thing. 

I posted a Question in one lecture, Edy responded in half an hour. You got to respect the guy. 

Do not search for other resource online if you are interested in PHP. 
Best of luck.

results.content:
I want to thank Edwin Diaz for his absolutely exceptional teaching skills and also for providing me with extremely fast one to one support and encouragement throughout this whole course.

This course is perfect for anybody that not only wants to learn about PHP but also for those that want to learn how to debug quickly and efficiently no matter your web dev language.

Usually I get bored learning languages but Edwin Diaz delivered his material in such an upbeat and fun manner that before I knew it, the course was over and I was thirsty for more.

I actually went out and bought a few courses on Javascript from other instructors before I started this course that I haven't started yet but if I feel they are not up to scratch I will certainly be coming back to Edwin's Javascript courses as I know I will enjoy every moment of it. 

I can't praise the man anymore than I have. He is the real deal! I wish him every success for now and into the future. Truly a man that cares, not only in this but in life. 

Thank you Edwin. :D

UPDATE 1 November 2016
I finally finished the course! Edwin kept on adding new content when I was close to finishing, which I now appreciate but have to admit at the time was a bit soul destroying lol. Lots of security stuff at the end which is very useful.

response.content:
You are welcome and it is a pleasure to produce high quality material for my students. I really appreciate you coming here and letting the world know, and for taking the time to do this. 

Thank you!

PS: I will relax a little with adding courses, just to give you guys some time to finish it :)

One hundred lectures in and there has been no context given for why php was created, what it's used for (outside of "facebook uses it") in terms of web architectures. He still hasn't mentioned the difference between client-side rendering and server-side rendering which is THE MAIN THING about php (which I learned elsewhere for free).

I'm a beginner web developer aiming to go professional and I don't feel this course covers the materials necessary to attain that standard or even really get you on the right path any better than free materials provided on youtube, reddit, etc...

The good: It does cover a lot of content and that which is covered is done competently. The lecturer is also very engaging. If you just need a broad overview of this language this course will serve your needs. 

If you really are looking to go from beginner to "master" - or more fairly let's say someone competent in the basics who understands the broad logic underpinning the choices made in structuring the language and its placement within the profession of programming, I would go elsewhere.

I don't have another example for php but for me an example of a very well designed udemy course is Andrei Neagoi's (I think that might be mispelled) web developer series, which focuses on react and node.js. I was looking for a php version of that, basically.

results.content:
I would recommend this course to anyone.  This is a must, especially if you're new to PHP.  You will learn A LOT!! I have a computer science degree, but nothing will compare to the repetition you get from the course while building your CMS system. 

I thoroughly enjoyed it.  Before long, I was writing code and queries before the instructor, because of the repetition.  Edwin is a great instructor. Take this from a 5+ years certified HS teacher.  He doesn't come across as someone who is so advanced that you can't understand what they are saying. He breaks down the lessons/concepts, and makes it easy to understand. And finding mistakes along with him is a great exercise.

His little motivational speeches can be humorous, but guess what??...This is the first course on Udemy I actually completed.  So it must have worked for me.  
Highly recommended. Thank you so much Edwin, you're making my career change go much smoother. I'm already using my CMS on two sites, one personal and one for a friend(client)..

results.content:
Instructor is highly disorganized, to the point where it was a little annoying to follow the course. Spends a lot of time re-organizing file structures and code blocks that should have been organized the first time they were set. It causes confusion and eats up the lecture time that could have been spent for something substantial and meaningful. He is also fickle, keeps changing his mind on a simple matter very often: for example, 'let's change this file name to B... no, it's fine as is. No, let's just change.' Making a few mistakes can be beneficial in that it shows how to debug, but he makes way too many simple mistakes that just waste the lecture time. 
He seems to have a good understanding of the materials (which he should) but overall, I felt the course lack in professionalism; it was like I was learning from a friend, not a professional instructor. 
Compared to four or five other courses I've taken on Udemy, this was the only disappointing experience. If you are someone that's bothered by lack of clean organization, I recommend you to take another course.

response.content:
I agree that I treat you like a friend and I also agree that I fix errors right on the spot; since I have been told its great to see the teacher debugging the app. Also, there have been times where I talk a little more but I do this so you don't fall asleep since that is common when studying any course :)

I want to thank Alex for his wonderful opinion and urge my future students to look at the positive reviews instead and know that this course has a no question asked money back guaranteed, just in case you don't like me :)

Thank you!

results.content:
As someone who already has some programming and Udemy experience, I find this course to be the worst of any that I had. Everything seemed nice and cool until I reached the CMS section. 

1. Indentation. Please make sure the code looks nice when you delete some parts of it. It really gets impossible to look at it after all those copy pastes.

2. Refactoring. Well okay, I get it - you do refactoring once you get all of the functionality working. BUT WHY??? Making separate functions from the very beginning makes it so much easier to code and to understand what is being coded. Also, so many copy pastes could have been avoided like that. God, it took so much time for me to understand what was going on when you decided to move the search function out of the sidebar.

3. Just a code along?? I believe it would have been much better if you gave instructions on what must be done and let us do it ourselves, giving a solution afterwards. Just like with the tasks after each section before the CMS. If you believe we could have trouble doing that, then you might give some hints, I don`t see a problem with that.

4. Way too many basic mistakes. Not even I (someone way less experienced I believe) do that much. 

All in all, I would not recommend this course neither for beginners nor for experienced. Beginners might find it too complicated and find the whole process of programming a mess, while experts will get a headache analyzing your decisions on postponing your refactoring to the future.

results.content:
El instructor:

Comete muchos errores y se devuelve a corregirlos en lugar de grabar nuevamente el video, haciéndonos perder mucho tiempo. Las clases parecen en vivo, y al cometer tantos errores solo evidencia la falta de dominio en el tema.

No es metodológico, los ejercicios no tienen un objetivo específico más allá de hacer funcionar un código.

En el 50% de las clases no da detalles sobre lo que está haciendo ni por qué lo está haciendo, solo dice cosas como "este código debo ponerlo acá" o "debo quitar esto de acá" pero no aclara las razones.

No utiliza adecuadamente los recursos, redimensiona las ventanas permanentemente en lugar de por lo menos usar ALT+TAB.

El curso inicia con ejercicios prácticos y evaluaciones y luego de la 5 sección (son en total 44) deja de hacerlo, lo cual demuestra el desinterés que tiene por hacer que el aprendizaje sea significativo.

Cambia el tono y volumen de la voz, lo cual dificulta usar los audífonos.

En resumen debo decir que el instructor ha hecho que aprender php sea confuso y una experiencia sumamente dolorosa.

results.content:
I started with PHP OOP course by Edwin Diaz. Though I have some experience with PHP (an individual study project last semester in grad school and a web development course in undergrad), I found I needed to refresh and strengthen my knowledge, so I have switched to the beginner course. I am determined to complete the OOP course as well.

I appreciate the great sensitivity and humor with which Edwin teaches. Though the course does jump back and forth a bit, as does its OOP counterpart, this is partly the nature of programming.

I feel I am learning a lot and gaining confidence as I go, and for this, I will be forever grateful to Edwin Diaz.

Sincerely,

Robert Hieger

results.content:
(Sorry for my bad english)


Sorry but i really can't tell anybody who wants to learn PHP to take this course. I thinks people posting good rating on this course don't realise that it's not a proper coding course.


While the teacher seems really enthusiastic, his teaching method is really bad and will lead any beginner to develop bad habits.


- He does lots of mistake

- He does lots of copy and paste between files, changing his mind, doing typos and so on...

- He doesn't indent his code properly, leaving tons of blank lines between blocks, it's driving me INSANE



Learning PHP as a language is a small thing, learning how to CODE properly is another and this course will not teach you that.

results.content:
I am only about 60% through the course, but I would highly recommend it for anyone new to PHP. He does a great job at explaining most things. (There are a few items he kind of skims past, but those are few. )
But, the main reason that I knocked a point off though, is that sometimes the code does not do what he intends for it to do when multiple data points are involved, or when tested on other values.  In other words, he doesn't test his code thoroughly enough to ensure it works completely.

Yes, technically the code works, but would it pass in a real world application, no. We all make mistakes, but the problem I have is when multiple people point out this potential flaw in the overall operation of the system, yet he doesn't revisit his code the way it would be for us at that stage in the course to ensure he didn't miss something. He simply thinks his code is working perfectly because it worked for that one row of data or that one altered value.

So, yes, please take this course as it will teach you a lot, but if a piece of code doesn't produce the results you think it should despite the code being technically correct, check out the comment section to see if others are experiencing the same result and how they fixed it. 

Edwin, I do thank you for the time you spent on this, and appreciate every minute of it, but please go back and understand why people are making the comments they are. Especially when they take the time to explain why.

results.content:
There is a long list of material that you get in this course.
1. php basics & essentials
2. php security
3. mysql
4. Login and Registration systems
5. A full featured CMS (content management system)
and more
A very comprehensive course indeed. Even though I have purchased other php and mysql courses, this one I keep coming back to for the CMS project. It really does walk you through php programming. This is great for beginners who want to get full stack development experience. 

My only criticism is that Edwin tends to ramble at some points which make the videos long but they do make for some entertaining, and at times, useful information. I highly recommend this course.

results.content:
The instructor's explanations are minimal. Basically you just watch him type out commands that are in the course files. The examples he uses are very basic, using short strings and small numbers. He tries to illustrate the use of functions, variables, etc., without properly explaining why they might be useful. All you see is that a number or a word showed up on screen in the end.  He also keeps repeating himself, wasting time on the video instead of explaining thoroughly what he's trying to teach. The fact that the videos are just a few minutes long, shows how detailed the instructions are. 
In some lectures he refers you to php.net. You might as well just learn from that website without paying for these videos.

results.content:
This course covered a lot of ground and the new features constantly being added do add value to the final project (a blog site with content management system). Edwin, the instructor is very relatable and engaging. 

The content of this course is great, however the delivery leaves much room for improvement. This course could use from a thorough reorganization and reshooting has it has grown much beyond its original scope.

Edwin's code is at best very messy, unorganized, and does not follow DRY principles. Debugging his frequent mistakes take up a large portion of the course time, but do provide real life examples of debugging for novice coders. More effort should be put in producing high quality work, as beginner students will leave this course with bad coding habits.

results.content:
Straightforward, very informative, and exciting. Edwin is a good instructor. I'm really learning a lot here. I'm filling more and more confident about being a web developer. Looking forward to learning more.

I've learned a lot about PHP here and feel very confident about using it as a backend language.

The course is very long. Most of the information you need will be covered by about 65% of the course. After that, it's extra features. 

The course was good and information but I wish it could be more straightforward and to the point with the core stuff you need. The extra features could also be better organized.

If you've taken computer programming in school, especially in advanced classes, you'll notice that some of the way code was written was not succinct and straightforward. The code could be improved. But, I think it's written that way because it's a beginner'sourse. The code could be neater and more succinct, nonetheless.

Overall, very informative, immediately applicable, and would recommend to anyone who desires to learn PHP. 4.5 stars!

results.content:
Very comprehensive course. You start at the basics then build an entire blogging system that could stand completely on its own, including the content management system "back end". The best value per dollar I've paid in a long time. But you should probably have some HTML and CSS experience before you start.

Edwin is very enthusiastic and positive. I don't hesitate recommending him as an instructor. It feels like he's just letting you look over his shoulder to show you stuff, not like you're in a stuffy classroom. I already have his other PHP courses queued up.

Edwin is engaging, and manages to empathise very effectively with his students - I get the impression he genuinely cares whether we progress, which is great.  Personally I'd prefer that the individual lectures were perhaps a bit longer, and covered a little more in the lectures - I'm about 1/6 of the way through - around 40 sections, and I think it could have been covered in a quarter of that.  But it's a small gripe, and he's a really good lecturer - you will not regret buying this chaps courses.

results.content:
One of the biggest issues with PHP community is that  it's not the language itself but how these people teach and learn this as first professional language. You see any Rails, Python Web or Nodejs course, they have Tests.  We don't expect people to write Unit tests but Functional tests are a minimum knowledge required to be hired in any team.

I would not hire anyone who cant write a simple test to demonstrate that they have the ability to test their code. Until this practice becomes the norm, I don't see a future for these PHP developers.

results.content:
This is not for a web designer/ developer looking to add PHP to their skill set; the pace of this course is for someone who has never opened a computer. I found it very hard to stay focused for this reason and because the instructor tends to repeat himself a lot ( the instructor felt the need to remind the student that his file structure may not match ours for the first 7 lectures ) and ramble.
I would think anyone looking to delve into PHP would at least have some knowledge of the web and would not need every single minute detail explained ad nauseam. 
After 3 hours I have gained nothing from this course.

results.content:
The course is probably the best PHP course in Udemy, so that's why I'm giving it stellar reviews. I feel the examples lack a depth and structure that I've seen in other Udemy programming courses, but that's personal preference--I just really like polished presentations.

If you have prior coding experience, you can breeze through a lot of the introductory coding lectures at 2x speed. Don't skim through the first sections on setting up XAMPP/MAMP/Brackets--it's the part that a lot of students struggle with (check the Q and A, lots of helpful info). 

I don't like how the course is taught using Brackets IDE--I'd rather be learning or using an IDE that is actually being used by more developers, but I'm sure I can research into it more.

Instructor/staff is really responsive to questions, answered me within a few hours. Download the resource files just to have them--they'll help you out if you're ever stuck debugging.

results.content:
I have started using what I learned for my job and I'm only half way done with this course. I usually won't rate until after completing a course, but even half way through I see the value.
some tips, make sure you are well rested and not distracted when taking the course. You will need to focus. Watch the videos once before attempting to code, then watch again and code along. This will save time in the long run. Edwin and Coding Faculty are very responsive and you will learn from reading the forums if you get stuck. I used this course to learn how to make a cms with a user login and a form where people can input data and retrieve a PDF. The PDF stuff came from somewhere else, but I used what I learned here to understand the PHP code on the PDF library. I will take more of Edwin's courses.

results.content: I like how the course is broken up into little chunks. It makes it easy to learn unlike a few other courses I've taken. That's why I would recommend this course to anybody. Having said that, I do wish the course was a little more polished. It feels like some time is wasted getting to the point. It's not a bad course by any means. I've found that video is far easier to learn from than most programming books are.  This course is great for beginners. If you have a lot of experience with PHP, or already program at an intermediate level, this course might drag on for you.

results.content: Although video alone is not really my preferred learning mode, I appreciated many things about this course: the scope and comprehensiveness; Edwin's explanations of what he is doing and why as he codes, along with recaps; his sense of humor; and his incredible responsiveness. At the time I completed the course, there were nearly 12,000 questions asked -- and answered, as far as I can tell. The Q&A section, therefore, makes for a great knowledge base. Additionally, when I hit one problem where I became completely stumped and reached out to Edwin, he took my whole database and codebase, combed through these, and delivered a solution in a few day's time. Amazing, especially given the total number of students he has among all his courses.

results.content:
I tried researching how to include google charts on my website and found this instructor's video for exactly that on youtube.  I did get something to work, but the structure of the line graph wasn't what I wanted. More research... When I found this course from the same instructor, I didn't hesitate to sign up. The thing is that I realized that I didn't understand php at all.
I'm currently about 1/3 of the way through the course content and I feel confident enough to troubleshoot my problematic script. It means I have learned much so far.  I'm looking forward to building the CMS course project.
Questions are answered promptly, even occasional off topic ones.
Thank you.
(p.s. Even three years after the introduction of this course Mr. Diaz is adding new content.  Also, more impressively, answering new questions on old content. I'm having a lot of fun applying what I've learned here on my live website.)

This was a great learning experience. As someone that had previous PHP knowledge, but had been out of the game for some years, it was a fantastic reintroduction back into PHP programming.

The project you build is a great CMS system, fully featured and an excellent framework to extend and build upon.

The instructor is engaging, highly knowledgeable and always there to lend a hand of you get stuck. He responds to messages really quickly and I found that to be a great benefit.

I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this course to anyone looking to get into PHP development, or to reacquaint themselves with the language.

results.content: Edwin is great. In this course he first goes over the foundations of PHP and then dives into a massive practical application project so you can really practice all the coding skills you just learned. Edwin is a very skilled teacher and a good speaker, he is very upbeat and positive which I didn't even realize I appreciated until half way through when his relentless encouragement is what kept me going. Edwin makes lots of mistakes but then goes back, finds what went wrong, and shows you how to fix them which some people might be annoyed with but I found it to be a very useful and encouraging teaching mechanism. This course is massive, he is constantly adding things to it, but its exactly what I needed to both learn PHP and be able to use it with confidence.

results.content:
Currently working through the course and I am very surprised at how much I am enjoying it.  Unlike other PHP courses I have attempted, but have yet to finish.  I find myself actually moving forward and gaining confidence as a PHP developer.  Edwin keeps you engaged in the material being presented with his passion for programming, wacky random data entries ( which generally begin with WOW man ), and his alter ego "Edwin from the future".
I have some questions regarding the recommended practices to secure PHP applications from various hacks and exploits  and how to properly code SQL prepared statements.  I look forward to completing the course, getting most if not all my questions answered, and adding an additional star to the course rating.
results.content_html:

results.content: You learn a decent amount(that is true for any course though), but the course organization is horrible. He spends so much unneeded time organizing his code. He also does not plan ahead. He will spend basically entire lectures redoing the same code from previous sections. This would have been avoided if he planned ahead and reused his code. By watching his lectures, you can tell he almost never reshot a lesson. This says to me that he thinks his time is more valuable than his students. If you value your time don't take this course. Additionally, he doesn't explain introductory concepts well. For example, he uses an API, but never explains what it is. If you are a beginner, then there will be a decent amount of sections that you will have to learn on your own.

results.content:
Edwin has a great personal style that for me worked out to be easy to listen to over hours of lectures. Don't underestimate the effect that the tutors voice has on audio lectures like these! 

He had a great pace a rhythm to his lectures and good solid content to learn. 

One problem, and he points it out himself. His folder structure is abysmal. Might sound petty, but when you are following along with your own work it adds a level of complexity and distraction that just didn't need to be there. A little extra work fixing his folder structures before filming would have gone a long way in my opinion. 

One other thing, every so often he would stumble or trip over his own words. This is not normally a problem, as it lends to the informal approach. But when he has to retype a code line more than twice, it gets real distracting, perhaps during filming a rule of redoing the take if he had to rewrite a code line more than twice would have made a more polished product.

In saying that, Edwin gets a solid 5 stars from me, as his content, pace and delivery do an excellent job of leaving me confident in using PHP at this level. And really, it is what I as a student learns that is the real measure of any course. I learnt ALOT!

Thanks Edwin.

results.content: Edwin rocks! If you are new to php or web development in general, this is hands down one of the best places to start. But, do not let Edwin's laid back teaching style and occasional humorous injections thwart your trust in his ability to show you the way to understanding how web development with php is done. The entire course is broken up into shorter, single concept video lessons, allowing you to absorb all concepts step by step and one at a time in a clearly presented manner with excellent audio and video quality. This allows you to learn at whatever pace is comfortable for you. At times you may wonder, 'Why is Edwin doing this that way?' But as you progress through the course, his methods will always become clearer, leading to real understanding of the why's and how's. By the time you finish the course, you will have gained a solid foundation in what is really going on behind the curtain on the World Wide Web.

results.content:
This course provided far more than I anticipated.  It works with a real application and makes many, many improvements to it.  It doesn't start out with the ubiquitous and terribly simplistic "Hello World" example.  We get into the heart of a CMS application immediately and "take off" from there.  
      It is also instructional to see the added features provided by scripting, javascript, and bootstrap. Even those this is not a course in that coding, the instructor wets one's appetite to take additional courses.
      The only negative I had during the first 205 lectures was in the introduction of the scripting section.  Certainly, a lecture had to be missing.  I had to dig into the Q&A to see how to create and then add the scripts.js file to the code.
      The instructor displays an unusual high level of interest in the students.  He is not aloof like some of the instructors for Udemy courses. 
      I have started several Udemy courses, but this is the first one I plan to finish to the very, very end (343 lectures) and probably want for more.
results.content_html:

results.content:
The reason I'm rating this course 3-stars is because of the instructor's code quality, the average content of the lectures and the constant marketing of other courses inside lectures.

Especially at the beginning it was very distracting to see the completely unordered, zoomed in codebases that the instructor was using to illustrate the various basics of the language. I believe that if complete beginners take this course (as they seem to be the target audience) then they should be presented with clean and transparent code that is easy to understand and follow. The impression I got was the complete opposite of that.

As for the contents, since the course has been first published quite a few years ago (2015 if I assumed correctly), many practices shown in the earlier sections are not considered best practices anymore. Some of these are corrected later, but not all of them, and once again, I don't believe it to be beneficial for beginners to study these topics without having an understanding of the more modern approaches. I think the course could also use a fairly long section about how PHP actually works behind the scenes, because that could be very valuable knowledge to aspiring developers.

The marketing - I think it's okay to say these things a few times at specific points in a course, as web development really is complex and other technologies are necessary in order to master it, but personally for me it was way too much. For a side note, the same goes for the motivational quotes - the instructor is having good intentions with them, but I came to learn PHP, not to start every lecture with 1 minute about either another course, or about how good I should feel because I'm progressing and I should be proud of myself.

With that said, I think this is still an okay course, but it doesn't live up to its potential. I think if the instructor revised the course it could be the best PHP course on this site, because he is 100% dedicated to what he's doing, as he's added multiple sections long after the original publication of the course. He is clearly a good person, and his work is appreciated, that's why I believe he could make this course even better if he refocused on the basics more, with better structural bases.

Some of these are corrected later, but not all of them, and once again, I don't believe it to be beneficial for beginners to study these topics without having an understanding of the more modern approaches. I think the course could also use a fairly long section about how PHP actually works behind the scenes, because that could be very valuable knowledge to aspiring developers.

The marketing - I think it's okay to say these things a few times at specific points in a course, as web development really is complex and other technologies are necessary in order to master it, but personally for me it was way too much. For a side note, the same goes for the motivational quotes - the instructor is having good intentions with them, but I came to learn PHP, not to start every lecture with 1 minute about either another course, or about how good I should feel because I'm progressing and I should be proud of myself.

With that said, I think this is still an okay course, but it doesn't live up to its potential. I think if the instructor revised the course it could be the best PHP course on this site, because he is 100% dedicated to what he's doing, as he's added multiple sections long after the original publication of the course. He is clearly a good person, and his work is appreciated, that's why I believe he could make this course even better if he refocused on the basics more, with better structural bases.

results.content:
I am rating this a 4 because no one is divine, the course isn't perfect but it is perfect for beginners! Here are some honest pros and cons...

Pros:
* Edwin goes above and beyond to explain in full detail how things work and why he is doing something. This course is highly recommended for anyone getting started with php.

* Edwin can't spell, so it constantly produces errors in the code and this is awkwardly good because it helps get you familiarized with troubleshooting your code from a very early stage. 

Cons:
* Fast learners will find that the high level of detail will eventually be extremely repetitive when you are beyond 50% of the course.

* Edwin refuses to use "Cmd + Tab" (Alt + Tab on Windows) to switch applications and continues to shuffle and resize windows around constantly.

* Course is for procedural PHP (instead of OOP), and while it isn't misleading or wrong, it is not what everyone is using for modern day programming. 

I also give udemy.com a -10 stars for not allowing any kind of formatting on their reviews.

results.content:
On the course outline you should tell people that they are expected to run certain pieces of software or to purchase certain pieces.  This would minimize any concern regarding supporting these classes.

In addition the instructor tends to assume that everyone is where he is in the program.  This course is listed as a Beginners course.  To tell the audience that you should know this stuff kind of defeats the term Beginner.  At the very least give some definitions of the actions that you are taking, explain why you are doing certain things just don't assume that because you add brackets to a statement that makes it work.  How about defining what a variable is and what if statements do and so on.  Maybe this course should have the first couple of lectures focused on defining the tools and statements that will be used to create programs.  Otherwise you can assume that you will lose your audience especially someone like me who has an extremely limited understanding of php and has never programmed.

results.content:
This is easily the best course I've taken on Udemy so far!

And at 16 courses of similar length, I am not saying this lightly. Edwin (the instructor) makes everything seem fun, easy, and do-able. At every point I felt like his code was not only understandable, but also incredibly efficient. As I made my way through the course, I started to feel like a natural - but Edwin didn't change his outlook. That meant that he was explaining stuff that perhaps I had already picked up on - but this made it so easy for when I had errors, and also made me feel like I was achieving something incredible, and actually learning as opposed to simply remembering.

If you are looking to learn PHP, or as I'm doing, use it as a refresher course, TAKE THIS COURSE! You'll thank your instructor after only a few lessons!

results.content:
I cannot say enough great things about Ediwn and his class.  This is not simply a copy and paste code class. You will learn procedural PHP. As many have said before me, Edwin is what makes this class so great.  At first I was thinking, "man, this guy can't type worth a flip" and I really didn't know what to think about the class.  As I went through all 240+ lectures I learned that as he made mistakes, we learn with him. Coding is more than just copying text. It's a process. You need to learn to think like a coder. Half of coding is searching for that missing semicolon.  He could have edited that stuff out, but in the end, it truly made it a better class.  I was also not very interested in the CMS project at the end of the class.  I don't really have a need for my own custom system. HOWEVER, that was probably the best part of the class. I learned something new in pretty much every lecture. Coding is more than syntax...it's interaction. It's learning to make all this stuff work together....adding functionality...fixing bugs.  Unlike other classes,  this class is not abandoned. There is an active discussion on the right hand side where students help each other out and Edwin is there to help if you get stuck.  FINALLY, there are new lectures constantly being added.  If you take one of Edwin's courses, you will probably want to take them all.   

I have noticed a few complaints that this class isn't Object-Oriented enough for them. He definitely teaches you how to refactor your code into objects, but if you really want to learn OOP PHP, take his course that is specifically about that.  That's where I'm heading now.

results.content:
Edwin delivers this course with enthusiasm and an earnest ability to teach people. For that I cannot fault him.

That being said, this course is all over the place. The code samples are poorly formatted and confusing. I never got the impression that Edwin was truly skilled in PHP or programming in general. He makes many mistakes and doesn't correct them until later. I understand teaching is hard, but most of this course seems poorly prepared.

It could have benefitted from using a script. He makes random comments and rambles often. Most of his technical explanations are also extremely vague or wrong altogether. Instead of writing code live, Edwin should have used prewritten code that is copy-pasted in and explained as he goes. Most of the later content is just fixing prior mistakes or security flaws in the code after hearing about it from students. This course could have been completed in half the time if it had been created with zero mistakes.

Edwin makes comments several time that this course was originally much smaller and has had many updates and changes. He says that this course is all about learning from mistakes. While I agree that's how learning is done, that is not how teaching is done.

Edwin put a lot of effort into this course, but most of it fell flat for me. For $10, it wasn't bad. All I can hope is that he's learned from his feedback and become a better teacher in the process.

results.content:
Refund.
Being a web developer for a 5+ years (working full time) I took this course to refresh my knowledge, maybe to learn something new, to see how certain things instructors do and to test it before recomending to my friends (because this one is rated as one of the TOP for beginners).

And I'm disappointed with this course because almost half, that I saw, didn't gave me any valuable information. Moreover, I clearly felt that I'm more experienced than the instructor and for a lot of things I would argue about the best way to deliver a particular topic to a student. I've noticed quite a few bugs, really bad practices of programming and architecture principles, use of outdated techniques and stuff. 

I know this intended for real beginners, but to learn from the ground up on a bad examples is not a good way to do. The author delivers a lot of topics, he actually know a lot, but in my opinion this course is not really good for those, who want to build a career of PHP developer and not as hobby just to make a personal blog themselves. Because if you want to learn PHP and become a competent specialist in 2017 you should not rush, learn more carefully and more deep, learn best practices and what tools, techniques and approaches to use, you should learn to understand why this function or this approache is used here, and not just copy&paste beacuse the instructor said so to build your first shiny CMS.

Sorry, I would not recoment this course.

results.content:
Wow I had to go all the way to the beginning. I'm about to embark on the section about php oop. 
I learned java under Dietel and Dietel. They were all about setting up getters and setters with the class variables that would become database fields, always harping on using private fields for encapsulation. It's a different coding style for sure. I'm sure that by the time the CMS hits production all the encapsulation that is required will be complete. In fact Netbeans and other IDEs will do a lot of the work in an automated fashion when we reach that level of expertise.
I learned some php under Larry Ullman. It was all procedural and the jobs on the market all require oop. So here I am with some prior knowledge but it feels like it's all puzzle pieces. Edwin I want to encourage you because I like your teaching methodologies. You present the material three times before moving on. A lot of these code snippets will be used in the CMS man that is imprinting the knowledge! We should all be able to return to the completed application and borrow modules (classes or groups of classes and any include files) as needed for future projects.
I give Edwin 5 stars because of the quality of the content both of his instructional videos and the code he gives us. Also he is there to answer our questions. I'm glad Edwin didn't just do what every talented developer does and go enterprise and chase money instead of helping all the students that got stuck along the way.
People if you get the code to work you did something.

results.content: Edwin is one of the best instructors i have seen, he explains everything so great, so easy to follow and understand. Unfortunately, after 40% completion of the course, when starting to build the CMS, he teaches the students to do that by a procedural method instead of the OOP method. The procedural method is VERY outdated and is not used any more is any of the leading CMS's or PHP frameworks. So, for very basic fundamentals, this course is good, for actually learning to write and use PHP it is very much outdated.

results.content: The instructor is very genuine. He makes mistakes (as we all do) and then uses the mistake to point out common errors to avoid. It's like he's sitting next to you at your work station working alongside you to achieve a common end. His depth of knowledge is very good. He exhibits not only a good grasp of the technical points, but also the practical application of the technical to solving every-day problems. You end up being able to actually use what you learn, which is a lot more than simply passing some kind of contrived certification exam.

results.content:
The structure of the course is good but the course is hard to follow. First, it is not the course. It just series of video that illustrate how to write PHP in each topics. Lack of explanation and preparation in each video. Second, the instructor makes too much mistakes. He always say 'mistake is good, I like mistake.' In my opinion, it's too much mistakes. It's really hard for me to follow up. Third, the video is unnecessarily long. I mean it can be cut the length of the video more than, I guess, 20% if he's on point. For example, in the custom search in section 12, there are 3 videos which represent each tiny step. But it takes like 10 minutes to just write a variable and check whether it's work. That's too much.  Forth, the instructor provide no code to follow up. Moreover, when he teach, he frequently change the code in his own pace. Like, you copy, new files, delete, paste like he create his own codes. This takes me lots of time to follow up in the really unimportant stuff.

I don't recommend anyone who want to understand the PHP and like the video that's on point to take this course unless you have some PHP book to read while studying this course or you really like his course structure which I find out that it covers most of PHP projects.

results.content: Edwin Diaz may be a great developer but he is not a very good teacher! His explanation for his repeated mistakes is nonsensical. His lectures are nebulous and undirected, they come across as very amateurish and unprofessional. He continuously states that seeing his mistakes teaches you how to fix your own, using this as an excuse for a poor quality course. Watching someone perform a service badly and continuously make silly errors shows incompetence, not expertise. Imagine being served at a restaurant and your order comes back wrong over and over again and the server gives you an excuse for why they are getting your order wrong. As a paying customer, no one cares about your excuses. We want a polished, professionally edited, professionally delivered,  and flawless product that we can utilize to seamlessly learn the information that we paid for and deserve.

results.content:
I was very pleasantly surprised with this course!

I have already had a decent amount of basic PHP experience on the side, teaching myself through various shorter online tutorials and a HeadFirst book. I was expecting this course to just be a quick review of PHP with a few new things to learn.

The first sections were basically as expected for this. However, the CMS sections are what make this course VERY special! In my prior learning resources, projects were fairly short and not as directed at full implementation for a real world project, nor did they do much testing, debugging, and refactoring as part of the workflow. 

The CMS project was extremely interesting and a great tool to teach multiple ways of doing common and useful website techniques that I hadn't seen before. I also think that doing everything on a single large project that evolved also made the learning more useful.

On top of that, Edwin has been great at coming back from time to time with new lectures for updates to existing techniques or expanding to new ones.

P.S. Even lectures such as how to prepare the website for being on a public server, and how to set that up, were interesting. I have already worked my way through how to do that on my own, but it was a tedious, unpleasant, trial & error process. I wish I had come across this course earlier in my web site development!
results.content_html:
I was very pleasantly surprised with this course!

I have already had a decent amount of basic PHP experience on the side, teaching myself through various shorter online tutorials and a HeadFirst book. I was expecting this course to just be a quick review of PHP with a few new things to learn.

The first sections were basically as expected for this. However, the CMS sections are what make this course VERY special! In my prior learning resources, projects were fairly short and not as directed at full implementation for a real world project, nor did they do much testing, debugging, and refactoring as part of the workflow.

The CMS project was extremely interesting and a great tool to teach multiple ways of doing common and useful website techniques that I hadn't seen before. I also think that doing everything on a single large project that evolved also made the learning more useful.

On top of that, Edwin has been great at coming back from time to time with new lectures for updates to existing techniques or expanding to new ones.

P.S. Even lectures such as how to prepare the website for being on a public server, and how to set that up, were interesting. I have already worked my way through how to do that on my own, but it was a tedious, unpleasant, trial & error process. I wish I had come across this course earlier in my web site development!

results.content: Edwin is a great guy and awesome instructor. Totally recommended!
results.content_html: Edwin is a great guy and awesome instructor. Totally recommended!

results.content:
This is one of the best courses I've taken online. Of all the Udemy courses I have purchased this is the one I've completed to 99%. It is clear, highly detailed, and will get you on your way to becoming a good web/PHP developer. 

I have to thank Edwin for making such a detailed quality course. Edwin's positive attitude is contagious and helped to keep me motivated through some of the more challenging parts. 

The challenging parts of the course had more than enough detail, which is one of the best aspects of the course. Edwin precisely explains the function of each each line of code you are writing.

 It is easy to make a small mistake when typing code, which sometimes causes a page to break. As any good instructor he provides examples of what may cause this. So by the end of the course you should be able to search and destroy mistakes on your own. 

Building a content management system is a good size project and you will learn a lot from this course. By the end of it you will have created something very cool, with the skills to become a skilled web developer. Even though I've been developing websites for 5+ years already I still learned a lot.

I highly recommend this PHP for beginners course.

Overall, this course was great! 

I come from an Operations background and wanted to get more knowledgeable about the developers I'm supporting.

Some of the topics were redundant for me since I've scripted many complicated scripts in shell and python...so some of it was redundant for me. (but it's always good to get a refresher!)

All in all this will get you comfortable with php and web development. It assumes some knowladge of HTML, CSS, and Javascript; but it's not strictly needed.

results.content:
Loved the course. 

The one thing I personally thought was a little lacking (hence my 4.5 stars) was the practice/reinforcement in the early section of the lectures. Now with my only gripe is out of the way I can focus on praise.

The projects are appropriate. I would strongly suggest this to a beginner programmer, or someone needing to get up to speed quickly on PHP. The items in the lesson are paced well. I personally turned the speed up to 2x because most of the concepts were familiar. The section on OOP really allowed me to get my head around OOP in a way that I was previously unable to.

So I paid very little for this course. It is worth at least 60 just for the lessons before building the CMS. A working CMS is worth a couple grand in just learning experience. So, if you read this and you are on the fence I would strongly encourage you to make the purchase.

results.content: As someone familiar with many different programing languages (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, and Java), this course is the perfect pace. The instructor speaks at a fast enough speed I do not need to use the speed up button, but not fast enough where I can't follow along. The structure of the course -- creating a separate file for each topic is great and is awesome for looking back on for reference. And lastly, the little quizzes at the end of each section and good wrap ups. My only constructive criticism is maybe including some higher level quizzes or projects for those who want a little more of a challenge. I know the course is for Beginners, but maybe just adding a little extra content can make this even better for Intermediate programmers too!

results.content:
I regularly take some of my spare time to learn PHP and coding in general. I mostly use this course as a reference and have watched the lectures several times. The instructor, Edwin is a decent tutor with a good amount of knowledge when it comes to PHP. At the beginning of the lectures he often greets the student and constantly reminds you to stay motivated, both at the beginning and at the end of the videos and he keeps pushing you to keep going, which is good :)

I have given this course 3 and a half stars because I notice when watching the lectures he is making simple spelling mistakes and not writing very simple PHP syntax especially when it comes to the beginning of the real world project (CMS) that you learn to make, once you have learned the basics of coding PHP. Overall the instructor (Edwin) constantly gives me the impression that he is maybe guessing/learning PHP as he is going along rather than knowing it off by heart.

This is all good PHP knowledge when it comes to the novice programmer e.g. someone who doesn't even know what programming is in the first place. When you visit forums and blogs on the internet and people say they have "expert" knowledge of such an extensive and broad language, you should not be making simple mistakes in your code such as adding .php extension to paths and filenames, and indenting also. 

When it comes to computers and technology these days, basic things like this should be of second nature like riding a bike. I can understand that English is not the instructor's first language but if I was taking this course as a complete beginner knowing what I know now I probably would not take this course and would say "go away and learn PHP in your own time" rather than relying on this course.

Last note: If you are thinking about taking this course or are about to and you do not have any previous knowledge of PHP or HTML, I recommend you spend some time reading a book on PHP learning the basics and fundamentals of PHP. I would recommend one called Visual QuickPro Guide. Otherwise you are really going to struggle with the project in the beginning because of how it is taught and you won't grasp the tutor's way of teaching.

Overall the instructor (Edwin) constantly gives me the impression that he is maybe guessing/learning PHP as he is going along rather than knowing it off by heart.

This is all good PHP knowledge when it comes to the novice programmer e.g. someone who doesn't even know what programming is in the first place. When you visit forums and blogs on the internet and people say they have "expert" knowledge of such an extensive and broad language, you should not be making simple mistakes in your code such as adding .php extension to paths and filenames, and indenting also.

When it comes to computers and technology these days, basic things like this should be of second nature like riding a bike. I can understand that English is not the instructor's first language but if I was taking this course as a complete beginner knowing what I know now I probably would not take this course and would say "go away and learn PHP in your own time" rather than relying on this course.

Last note: If you are thinking about taking this course or are about to and you do not have any previous knowledge of PHP or HTML, I recommend you spend some time reading a book on PHP learning the basics and fundamentals of PHP. I would recommend one called Visual QuickPro Guide. Otherwise you are really going to struggle with the project in the beginning because of how it is taught and you won't grasp the tutor's way of teaching.

results.content: When this course begins you think OK what have we here? But if you are a beginner like me, it becomes pretty obvious pretty quickly that you are exactly where you need to be.  Edwin's easy delivery is infectious, and it gives you the confidence you need to try new ideas. What I really like is that Edwin takes the time to explain things that are assumed in other courses.  Those assumptions are very unhelpful for beginners, so its great to find an enthusiastic instructor who still gets what it is really like to learn from scratch.  No reservations I would recommend this course  to anyone wanting to know more about PHP and CMS systems.

results.content:
I have completed the full course right from the beginning and I really want to write a review about this course and this amazing instructor.

About the instructor: He is really amazing instructor which thinks about his student, listen to their problems, add additional features depending on the requirement, wants you to do well in your course and life as well, is a good motivator, and will keep you engaging all the time with his funny speech.

About the course: This course is perfect for complete beginners and even if you have an intermediate knowledge, it starts with the basic knowledge of PHP, you will find good and useful practical exercises to-do along with the course, this course demands a bit of knowledge in HTML, if you don't have it that's okay you'll catch up.

In the latter part of the course you will find lectures on Database and then you will make a project along with the instructor.

This is a very slow paced course so you can watch it according to your own speed, I preferred watching it on 1.25X and 1.5X sometimes.

QnAs are answered within 24 hrs, as well as the instructor keeps on adding new features to it, will keep you up-to-date.


A bit of con about the course: At various places, I found that things could have been done in a better way but later on instructor made a video on how to do things in a better way, both of the ways are of same difficulty level but just have a different methodology which could have been done at first place by just introducing the other one, it happened at quite a few places but then it is alright as you will get to know more about things.

You might get a bit pissed off on silly mistakes in typing and syntax that instructor makes in the initial part of the videos but then Instructor always comes up with a joke to compensate. 

One of the best thing that I like about this course is, it motivates you to work on the course along with it, there will be places where the instructor will deliberately leave something for you to think on them, and will later help you out in solving them.

Overall it is one of the best course that I have taken. You will have a lot of fun taking it. So go for it, you will learn a lot of things.
Take care.

Keep Learning, Happy Coding :)

results.content: To Edwin. The overall content of this course is definitely great, including the coding that is commonly repeating the same process to query the database so a beginner can get used to query the database along this tutorial, but the methodology you used to teach perhaps could be much better for example: It's a pain ass to follow your coding because when you scroll up and down through the code file, you do it too fast and let me feel so dizzy to follow and also when you change among files to copy paste a code. Much of the time I get lost and it's difficult to debug the code for the same reason I just explained. For my experience till now, with this course, I can say that this one is not for absolute beginners, because the lack of the explanation of some of the code. for example when you teach a beginner, you should use something like var_dump($object) or print_f(Object_array)  to show us how the code behind scenes works. FYI, I had to stop following this course for a couple weeks, because I found a nice php tutorial in youtube to let me clarify my mind about PHP foundations, then I just go back to follow this course again. And another thing is that often, the videos are so blurry and it didn't play smooth on my side. I live in Taiwan and the internet speed here is so great. I have 350 mbps for downloading. I already submitted a request to Udemy to set an option in the pc udemy browser version, to let me download all my course videos in order to watch them offline on my PC, in the case of this terrible situation happens again, that I can't watch the videos smoothly. BTW thank you so much for your effort. Peace out

results.content:
I have only taken a couple of courses on Udemy before and didn't find that they benefited me at all. Some people may differ but i can't learn by staring at someone's powerpoint and just reading the information. Edwin understands that people don't learn in that way and he has created a superb interactive course that can teach you all about PHP in a matter of weeks or months or even years. Its up to you how fast you complete it! With practise exercises at the end of each section and reminders throughout the course on every little thing you have learnt, you would have to be pretty good to forget it. 

Edwin manages to deliver the course in a user friendly way and has helped hundreds if not thousands of people find their way into becoming a php master!    

If you are a complete beginner in PHP or need to improve your skills in PHP, i strongly recommend this course!

results.content:
In short, I would give this course a 4 out of 5. I really considered rating lower but it has an odd way of teaching me PHP. I only have a basic understanding of web development (~ 4 month of working on it) and knew nothing about PHP. **If you have a decent understanding another language like javascript (backend js esp) then I would do a couple of the first few lectures then just skip to the CMS. I say this because the CMS project is a great teaching tool and even after a few lectures I was able to see what we were trying to accomplish and begin filling this out with the video paused and double checking with Edwin's work.

Speaking on the teaching - I feel like I am learning everything with Edwin. That has been a double edged sword because I don't get a feeling of confidence from Edwin's work - very lackluster, doesn't pay attention to detail and makes many mistakes that stem from not concentrating and planning. On the other hand it's reinforcing what I am doing because I am spotting his mistakes and working through problems with the videos paused which is helping me learn.

I get a feeling from the lectures that Edwin is learning as he is going along, which may not be the case but it's been a good way for me to learn - why I gave it 4 stars. BTW Edwin from the future is FRICKING LOUD!!! haha I haven't seen one of his new courses but really suggest to him that he plan out projects and videos a little better to make sure he stays on topic and makes things clear. As said by previous commenters that he wonders around quit a bit which could be tough for a new learner.

results.content:
I find that Professor Diaz is very kind and likes to explain as much as he can about the different functions and subject matter.

I have completed a number of lectures so far, up to the reading from MySQL databases and have learned a lot.

The only thing that I would recommend to Professor Diaz and any other lecturer in computer science is to go more in depth about different functions with a programming language. I would recommend describing the differences and some extra functions that may be similar to one another. An example of this may be the var_dump vs print_r functions. 

Also, I know that it is common to store the MySQL connection information into separate variables and do not know if this will be covered in the course. I am new to MySQL and would definitely like a little bit more clarification on this language, relational databases, and PHP My Admin. However, I do know that he has mentioned that there is enough information to make it another course (just slightly more clarification).

All in all, great course and I am looking forward to learning more PHP!

This course is probably the most detailed course of PHP in Udemy. 
There are indeed scopes of improvement, specially in organizing the course material. Towards the end it loses steam, and sometime feels a bit lengthy as well.

But what I liked the most about this course is Edwin was not interested in hiding the bugs and errors made while writing the codes, rather he encouraged to make mistakes, and fix them. This way we learn better. And also not to mention his playful way of teaching, it helps the student to readily connect with him. 
Thank you Edwin for making a nice course.

results.content:
If you see this rating probably you will not take it in consideration as I did after seeing the percentage of good rating, that I do not understand in this moment.
Unfortunately I purchased this course along with another bunch and until I reached this one the guaranty period expired so I was “forced” to watch it till the end, hoping it will get better, but it got worse.
During the course, it is obvious that Edwin never had a plan when designing this course. It has no course logic it is almost recorded live with a lot of mistakes. Making mistakes is normal and helps you learn but not when you are the instructor and you waste 3 minutes out of a 4 minutes video to find that mistake.
This course can be easily reduced to less than half of its time, a lot of time wasted in finding errors and refactoring because it was not planned before as it should be.
Even if you follow the code step by step, your code doesn't work as you might expect, because the instructor does a lot of refactoring behind the scenes that he forgets to show us and his response is: please compare the code with the one from the final files attached to the course. This is not the good way of teaching.
Many times he does not explain the code even if at the beginning of the course he explains to many times the most obvious and simple code lines, and then after the first lectures it writes code and sends us to the PHP documentation if we want to find out more.
