results.content:
First off, Edwin is a very knowledgeable instructor and a genuine, nice guy. I would purchase more courses from Edwin.

Okay so I managed 234 lectures before stopping, here's why.

Literally everything within the course worked like a charm, not always first time, but eventually I got everything how it should be (the lecture questions are VERY helpful btw). So in the end, I have a fully functioning CMS, which is what I wanted. (screenshot of my final admin dashboard: https://i.imgur.com/2gtSBTL.jpg)

However, I stopped the course early as I felt it had taught me everything that it was going to teach me - I dare say I was beginning to be taught things the wrong way of doing them using a billion variables all named differently etc.. even if this is for beginners, DRY code should be taught & encouraged, unfortunately it isn't here.

The one major gripe I had with the course was the user system. This was pretty bad. Edwin probably realised this and revisited it no fewer than 3 times, each time completely rewriting the system. This obviously had a knock on effect throughout the CMS which wasn't properly taken care of to ensure everything worked smoothly.

The course needed to be better planned I feel. I believe this was quite an old course of Edwin's that was updated multiple times over the years, so I'll give the benefit of the doubt to Edwin. Watching him stumbling through code, making typo's and telling me how awesome I am could very easily have been edited out :D

All in all, I'll give the course 4 stars. 

If you're a n00b at PHP, or just want to know how to tie up a database with PHP using PROCEDURAL PHP ONLY, then this course is without doubt the best one on Udemy.
results.content_html:
First off, Edwin is a very knowledgeable instructor and a genuine, nice guy. I would purchase more courses from Edwin.

Okay so I managed 234 lectures before stopping, here's why.

Literally everything within the course worked like a charm, not always first time, but eventually I got everything how it should be (the lecture questions are VERY helpful btw). So in the end, I have a fully functioning CMS, which is what I wanted. (screenshot of my final admin dashboard: https://i.imgur.com/2gtSBTL.jpg)

However, I stopped the course early as I felt it had taught me everything that it was going to teach me - I dare say I was beginning to be taught things the wrong way of doing them using a billion variables all named differently etc.. even if this is for beginners, DRY code should be taught & encouraged, unfortunately it isn't here.

The one major gripe I had with the course was the user system. This was pretty bad. Edwin probably realised this and revisited it no fewer than 3 times, each time completely rewriting the system. This obviously had a knock on effect throughout the CMS which wasn't properly taken care of to ensure everything worked smoothly.

The course needed to be better planned I feel. I believe this was quite an old course of Edwin's that was updated multiple times over the years, so I'll give the benefit of the doubt to Edwin. Watching him stumbling through code, making typo's and telling me how awesome I am could very easily have been edited out :D

All in all, I'll give the course 4 stars.

If you're a n00b at PHP, or just want to know how to tie up a database with PHP using PROCEDURAL PHP ONLY, then this course is without doubt the best one on Udemy.

results.content:
Fantastic course. Coming from a Java background, this started with the PHP basics, then passed through everything I needed to refresh my very very little XAMPP exposure so far.

After the basics we start on the CMS and that's when it picks up steam. After a while I could see how to do stuff so just by the first seconds of each course I could made what was being requested and then I watched the video to be sure I was right.

He speaks slowly and adds a bit of small talk. Some people might not like it, but it was fine by me. It added a bit of human touch and a good environment for learning.

On the basics I watched at normal speed, after a while, when learning new stuff I started watching at 1.5x and when just making sure I made everything right, I watched at 2x.

This makes everything better if you are already versed in programming.

I like how he gradually adds new concepts and functionalities to the system. 

I feel much more comfortable with the PHP concepts and approaches to web development and I'm only at half the course. Can't wait to finish everything!

All in all this course is well worth it!

results.content:
Man, this guy is awesome! I ended up learning some pretty awesome stuff from this course. Honestly, I expected a basic CMS project that explains how the basic PHP functionalities works but walked away with way more content than I'd ever expected. 

Truth be told, I always used to be on the fence on how to go about certain bits of code in PHP in my projects; constantly doubting my logic every step of the way and that kinda bogged my productivity down, but now, I feel pretty confident to take on real-world projects with the stuff I ended up learning, y'know? Edwin goes out of the way to add extra content to the course and as the chapters progress, you end up learning more and more awesome bits of code.

I'd definitely recommend this course to anyone just starting out with PHP or for someone who's looking to use PHP in a more practical sense.

Man, this guy is awesome! I ended up learning some pretty awesome stuff from this course. Honestly, I expected a basic CMS project that explains how the basic PHP functionalities works but walked away with way more content than I'd ever expected.

Truth be told, I always used to be on the fence on how to go about certain bits of code in PHP in my projects; constantly doubting my logic every step of the way and that kinda bogged my productivity down, but now, I feel pretty confident to take on real-world projects with the stuff I ended up learning, y'know? Edwin goes out of the way to add extra content to the course and as the chapters progress, you end up learning more and more awesome bits of code.

I'd definitely recommend this course to anyone just starting out with PHP or for someone who's looking to use PHP in a more practical sense.

results.content:
This a fantastic course ! First and foremost Edwin is a fantastic instructor. It's hard (If not impossible!) to find any criticism of his teaching style.

It starts with an overview of PHPs syntax and the how to use the basic functionality. Which is brief enough for people who have a little knowledge of PHP but detailed enough for those that don't.

It then moves onto building an entire CMS. This is planned out exceptionally well. Small chunks of the CMS are built at a time which enables students to be able to do as little or as much as once as they would like at a time. Wether you have 30 mins a day or 3 hours a day ! 

Edwin does a fantastic job of explaining his code. His teaching methods are also of very high quality. Just enough repetition of the code without it seeming like repetition for the sake of it. Edwin makes it clear when he thinks it's time for the student to be able to code it without his help.

After the initial CMS has been built (Approx 1/2 way through the course content) there are many many lectures about adding extra features. These are awesome ! Including lectures on extra security, taking the project online and AJAX (My personal favourite section of the course).

By the final sections Edwin gives a brief introduction about more advanced PHP topics. Like using Prepare statements and using extra software to install PHP libraries.

A very good course. I am looking forward to taking another of Edwins Courses.

results.content:
I'll just start off by saying that Edwin Diaz's courses are so worth the money. 

Why I enjoy Edwin's courses so much is that he doesn't read from a script. Everything Edwin does is an example of what it's like to program in the real world. Sure, some people may not like that and think it's unorganized but this really is the best way to learn. Errors and mistakes, we do them all the time in general and we always learn from it. They always say, a program will never run successfully the first time.

Real world projects are what Edwin creates during his courses and that is what makes them so great and easy to learn from. By following along with Edwin, he explains what his code does and seeing an actual example of the code really helps with taking in what you've learned.

Before starting his PHP for beginners course, all I knew was how to create a variable in PHP. After completing the fundamentals and the CMS project I now have more knowledge than I expected to have. I basically bought the course expecting to be able to understand PHP code and its basics. I now have the knowledge (Just from this course alone) to create login systems, content management systems and much more.

There are some things to note in this course about security aspect of things. During the beginning of the CMS project, the code isn't secure and will be vulnerable to attacks. But this is later brought up in the extra lectures and solved (Better password hashing method, protection again SQL injection and XSS attacks. So I thought I'd just mention that in case anyone was actually planning to make their project live.

The courses I have purchased from Edwin are;
- PHP for beginners - Become a PHP master - CMS Project
- PHP Security
- PHP Ecommerce project
- PHP Login and Registration system
- PHP OOP for beginners
- PHP Laravel for beginners
- PHP MVC Framework CodeIgniter

So yeah, I can recommended his courses. This all based on my personal opinion though, so yours may be different, with that said, there's no harm in trying it out.
results.content_html:
I'll just start off by saying that Edwin Diaz's courses are so worth the money.

Why I enjoy Edwin's courses so much is that he doesn't read from a script. Everything Edwin does is an example of what it's like to program in the real world. Sure, some people may not like that and think it's unorganized but this really is the best way to learn. Errors and mistakes, we do them all the time in general and we always learn from it. They always say, a program will never run successfully the first time.

Real world projects are what Edwin creates during his courses and that is what makes them so great and easy to learn from. By following along with Edwin, he explains what his code does and seeing an actual example of the code really helps with taking in what you've learned.

Before starting his PHP for beginners course, all I knew was how to create a variable in PHP. After completing the fundamentals and the CMS project I now have more knowledge than I expected to have. I basically bought the course expecting to be able to understand PHP code and its basics. I now have the knowledge (Just from this course alone) to create login systems, content management systems and much more.

There are some things to note in this course about security aspect of things. During the beginning of the CMS project, the code isn't secure and will be vulnerable to attacks. But this is later brought up in the extra lectures and solved (Better password hashing method, protection again SQL injection and XSS attacks. So I thought I'd just mention that in case anyone was actually planning to make their project live.

The courses I have purchased from Edwin are;
- PHP for beginners - Become a PHP master - CMS Project
- PHP Security
- PHP Ecommerce project
- PHP Login and Registration system
- PHP OOP for beginners
- PHP Laravel for beginners
- PHP MVC Framework CodeIgniter

So yeah, I can recommended his courses. This all based on my personal opinion though, so yours may be different, with that said, there's no harm in trying it out.

results.content:
This is a very hard course to follow, engage in, and even apply as a craft for coding in PHP.  Here are some spoilers:

The speaker makes a lot of mistakes through the course. What I mean is that he'll write a customized piece of code, then some time later in the future will go back and fix it.  This happens a lot! Get ready to do double work!  It appears he is going off of memory for little things while coding, but fails to remember to do it the right way the first time.

The speaker is coding with a procedural approach, but gives no convincing reason why this is a solid practice for new developers of PHP.  Get ready for messy PHP / HTML pages with no separation of concerns.

Copy and paste of PHP code is widely used in this entire lesson. The speaker may not be aware, but It clouds the craft, or "the art" of a new developer knowing PHP as a subject matter.

The speaker provides his personal abstractions, but gives no reason why it is a solid practice over other approaches.  Same goes for the SQL scripts being applied.  You just have to trust him...

The speaker leaves many things up to the new developer to know .  i.e. He mentions no use of security, sanitizing, validating or filtering of data to and from the database.  Be aware that safe practices are not in parallel with this course. 

The speaker keeps asking if something is right, but who would really know when there is no road map, blue print, or consistent coding behavior being applied.  Every next move is different from that last.  It feels as though he is talking to himself and no one else really knows where to go next.

In conclusion, I'm glad I had a chance to see a transparent look on procedural coding in PHP.  So far its a nightmare, but it gives me knowledge on what not to do moving forward.

results.content: The instructor is enthusiastic, which is nice, but he seems to be making a lot of mistakes (not to mention he doesn't indent code properly which driving me insane), talks excessively about very basic topics and seems unprepared. The whole course feels slapdash and unprofessional. The OOP section was particularly badly explained. Real life examples are lacking in the first 11 sections. For example, the classes implemented in the OOP section were Car and Dog with sample methods such as MoveWheels and CreateDoors (for Car obviously) - hardly inspiring; while the lessons on cookies and sessions only show syntax. I wouldn't recommend this course.

results.content:
The course is very thorough. Once the CMS is completed, the instructor continues adding features, fixing bugs, and giving us more practice. The course could include a little bit more theory on the language, but I understand that, being so practical, it is not the intention.

The instructor shows experience and is relatable. He makes mistakes, finds them, fixes them, just like in real development. Of course, he could repeat the recordings to show a version without the errors, but then we would miss the process of how he finds them, and the explanation. I find it actually positive for learning.

I can only find three problems with the course:
- His code formatting (indentation) is very sloppy. This, of course, is common among web developers, and he fixes it a bit as the course progresses (especially when he changes to an IDE).
- For most of the course, he calls the variables that hold the results of queries with a name that implies that they are queries. He later changes this, I suppose somebody also told him. I wouldn't redo all the videos just because of this, but I think that "Edwin from the future" could give a small explanation when this is first done.
- He completely skips SQL aggregate functions when they would be more efficient (Edwin, my friend, COUNT() is faster than counting the rows of the returned dataset!).

I will recommend this course to any friends who are interested in learning PHP.

results.content: Edwin, my dear teacher. I am so happy I took your course on PHP. I've currently taken a few other courses on Udemy on Node.js and other web technologies, but none of them had you as a teacher. I have such a solid working understanding of PHP and know that I can easily start building websites with CRUD including additional features. Passing around parameters, using a database, and encrypting data. There will be issues at times or things you have to work through, but you showed me that it's all part of the process. You're attitude, enthusiasm, and desire to help your students is outstanding. I've realized that I love programming and I do it everyday whether it's my own projects or course material. You're courses will definitely help me become a better programmer for sure and I will be taking more courses in the future. Thank you so much Edwin!!

results.content:
Firstly I want to thank Edwin for teaching this course well.

Pros:
Awesome instructor. Always keeps you awake and pushes us to finish the course. 
Motivating.
I could understand and develop PHP applications on my own after this course. 
Excellent Support. He says he is available 24 x 7 and its true.

Cons:
The only big problem is Edwin is not organized. Example, the functions are not written in the functions page, he writes it off in the main page and scatters it everywhere.

We can avoid that clutter by doing our work neat. Edwin teaches us to write functions initially but does not follow. But we can actually follow and keep it neat.

Overall fantastic course.

results.content:
I think the course is actually really good. The instructor goes a bit fast at times which causes me to have to stop and rewind a bit. I would also like to see a few more practice projects for each concept. For example, we jumped from Variables to arrays really quickly without practicing them. I paused and copied exactly what the instructor was doing and then ran it so that helped. I would like to have a bit more structured and guided practice though. Coming from learning other languages at the same time I was alright but for a total beginner, i would be overwhelmed by the speed and lack of practice for each concept. 
The attitude and knowledge of the instructor are top notch though. He's very upbeat and encouraging and it's apparent he is very comfortable with the material and knows what he's talking about. If you're tech savvy or are willing to pause a lot and do a little self-guided practice than I think you'll get through the course fine. I'm enjoying it for sure and would take another course from the same instructor even if it was 100% new to me.

results.content: well, edwin seems to be a great guy, he really is passionate in making the course and in making the videos nice and friendly. but as much as i do want to give a good rating for this course (cause he really seems to be a great guy), I just can't give it more than 3,5 stars. problem is he isn't that good at teaching in my opinion (he tries, but he isn't able to go to detail in the important basics, nor explaining some basic principles of the language.). The so called "exercises" are pretty much useless (speaking of the practice sections or also the quizes, since they are so superficial and without concrete challenges, for example it's like "now try to make an array with 5 things in it^^)). the idea of making an own cms with php is great, however, there is so much time invested in just deleting html from the bootstrap template, it's not worth it. you can ask yourself "well, this course only costs me about 10 - 20 euros. is it worth 10 or 20 euros?". then the answer would be yes. cause for 10 or 20 euros you get a lot of content. HOWEVER: you also have to ask yourself "is it worth the time?". and this question is a difficult one for me. a pro argument for this course is that it seems that there literally are no good php-courses here on udemy. there are good css courses, good javascript courses, good mysql courses, but I didn't find a good php course yet. this is one of the "better" courses I did find. But still, a con argument is that you just will learn php very superficial and there is a lot of time in this course you waste with senseless things, like for example deleting a bunch of html and so on. in fact, the lack of good php courses made me think if I will make my own php-course someday. but first i have to learn the language in depth. I don't know why there are so much high ratings, I just think it's because udemy asks you very fast if you want to give the course a rating, then most of the people just have started with the course, are very euphoric and think "well, seems to be a great guy, I'm sure the whole course will be great too, even if I just watched 3 videos so far! let's give it 5 stars!" and probably sometime in the future they lose interest and then they don't continue with the course, just leaving it there with a 5 star rating. I may be wrong, I may be right, who knows. Nevertheless I'm going to finish this course, cause since there are just a lot of shitty php courses out there, this one is atleast one that is able to learn you a bit php. so not hate edwin, I'm sure you are a great guy and also a great programmer, but this course isn't the yellow of the egg, as we say in germany.

results.content:
TL;DR: This course starts with some simple, practical lessons and exercises about PHP, but really soars once you start section 12 about building your own CMS. This super-expansive course will help you see the bigger picture of PHP, and Edwin is very effective in teaching the steps needed to building your dynamic website.

Pros:
- Amazing quality and value!
- Lots of relevant/accurate content!
- Great teaching by Edwin from the beginning to the end of building of a CMS.

Neutral:
- Sometimes I got lost because of how many lessons there are, and I would have to consult the PHP manual for alternative solutions to problems --> but this is a GREAT stimulus to improving my understanding.
- The course leans on bootstrap/jquery which isn't really an issue because this is a PHP course, but I avoided jquery simply because I prefer vanilla Javascript.

Cons:
- There's some reliance on jquery, which in practice is used a lot, but it can be confusing to those who don't have any jquery/javascript knowledge.

Conclusion:
- Would recommend to everyone wanting to learn PHP.
- Would definitely take this course again!

Conclusion:

results.content:
Let me kick off with the reason I've bought this course, followed by the negative stuff and ending with the positive stuff about the course.

Why did I buy it?
I'm a webdesigner and I want to get into programming. I've been trying to get into programming often before, with languages such as Javascript and C#. I never really got it. I decided to give PHP a try because it's part of something I already understand and I can connect it with (HTML / CSS).

The negative stuff:
It's a great course and I have gotten out if it what I wanted, to understand PHP and basic programming. However like most courses, it ain't perfect. So there we go:

- I felt like during the course, it suddenly made a jump from the very basics to -at that point- pretty advanced stuff with the post superglobal. Suddenly creating mysqli queries and such really confused me for a while. It seemed like the chapter afterwards should have been first.

- Even though Edwin tries to often explain how stuff works, he's not the best at it. Often the explanations are quickly and not clear. He makes up for that by working in a way that is easy to follow and to understand, but the explanations themselves could be better.

- Later in the course Edwin starts to include Java and sometimes AJAX into the code. Really nice, but he does not explain how it works and the only thing you get is: 'If you don't understand Javascript, just do what I do. Since this is a PHP course I won't explain it and I have a great course for you about Javascript where I explain everything'. This started to annoy me after a few times. We're not here to listen to advertisement for another course, neither do I want to copy code of which I've no idea how it works. I tried it while including something called 'CKEditor', it gave me an error and until now I don't understand how to solve the error(s).

- Edwin sometimes jumps to a different editors. Later on when you get the gist of it, that doesn't matter anymore. But if you are having issues with understand the written code on itself, that can be confusing.


The positive stuff:
Just to summarize. I've learned what I wanted to learn. I'm right now at section 30 and just watching for a sport and inspiration for what to do next. I understand mostly everything and I'm by now usually working ahead of Edwin and after that watching if what I did was right and/or can be improved.

Edwin seems generally happy, positive and he likes to motivate you almost every single chapter to keep going. Sometimes maybe even a little bit too much. He is a very nice instructor to listen to.

I would totally recommend this course. I've learned a lot from it and I had a lot of fun with it as well. Everything seems very up2date, I did not have any issues with for example outdated code or whatsoever. There's a lot of content and inspiration. Far after you are done with the basic CMS there is still so much to improve and create and Edwin is there to show you all of it.

4 out of 5!

results.content: This has been such a fun course. I am coming into this with a bit more experience in programming than probably the average student here and I am learning a lot. This course has really helped me learn what's different about PHP. Edwin has made me really enjoy PHP, something I never thought I'd ever say. If you're a newbie or someone that just wants to expand their horizons to PHP, like me, then you will love Edwin's passion and ways of explaining things. He's a very upbeat and positive person that makes the boring stuff a lot more exciting! Thank you Edwin, I'll be looking into your other courses very soon!

results.content:
Excellent course so far and the teacher is excellent ! my only minor gripe is he does uses bootstrap (which is not a problem, which is why I gave him 5 stars) .  Just my own preference is that I wished he did not use bootstrap in his cms section, and rather gave us an example alongside the php integration without it, as i want to use as less frame works as possible.  However what he teaches about PHP is so extremely helpful, (that is what he advertised) I want to stress again this is not really an issue, the course is extremely good. If you know HTML and CSS then removing his bootstrap integration is possible, it just takes time.

I purchased his other courses.

results.content: I managed to finish 45% of the whole course, and I already know a lot of things. It's a lot of interesting information, also fun sections where you really have fun doing them. Beginners might find some lectures confusing and hard to understand because he is making mistakes. As a beginner in PHP I was stuck so many times trying to understand why it's not working right. If you will have  the same problems as I did, my recommendations are to start reading php.net, stackoverflow.com, quora.com and ask questions in the Q&A. It wasn't a big problem for me to find and solve the problem, that's what programmers do I understand but the fact that I was a beginner made me sometimes angry, and was losing motivation. Thank you.

results.content: The delivery of these lectures to date is great.  However, like problems with many online courses and books, they go out of date.  Not sure if Tutors are able to update their lecturers, but the MAMP screens are out of date.  Also on a MAC, if you have MAMP open and you right click on the MAMP icon you have the options to keep the icon in the doc, and to load MAMP when your MAC boots.  This saves time fiddling around with starting the Apache server and MySQL.  Apart from this it is thumbs up so far.  Love it.

results.content: You did an excellent job of teaching the basics of PHP! This was one of the better put together courses that I have taken on Udemy. My only request is that for newer programers, your lack of attention to white space throughout the course (and in the example files) was atrocious. My concern on this is that newer programmers will end up not paying attention to white space and have to break poor habits once they get to the point of employment. I charge you with working on that. Other than the white space driving me crazy this class was above and beyond. Great work Edwin!

results.content:
This course is sloppy and unprofessional. The instructor is constantly making mistakes and making you watch him figure out his problems. He does not pay any attention to code formatting, which is just as important as the code itself.

I looked at his credentials, and his only experience was a CS degree from University of Phoenix. I'm glad he was able to learn on his own time a find a way to make money, but he's teaching bad habits.

Unfortunately, PHP has a bad reputation because there is a lot of sloppy code out there, and I don't think this course is helping.

results.content:
So far I think you can deliver the information well, but you must definitely find a solution for your "resolution problem" and help keep your files and code cleaner. 
It just helps out a lot in making the whole lecture less confusing. 

Also I'm into PHP Databases but so far I haven't seen any real, concrete projects. You know, just examples. I hope to see them later, but it definitely would have been appreciated to have some early on as well. I think it helps the student have a better guidance. 

But you're a nice, fun, and knowledgeable instructor otherwise. I like the course content.

*** edit 
- And comment your code!! I haven't seen you do that at all and I think for beginners it's really important to show them. :P

results.content:
I feel like I really have gotten the hang of PHP. That was what I needed, so therefore I must give a 5.

I am thankful for that. The value of getting so much practice is well worth the price. There is a lot of repetition as we make functionalities for blog posts, comments, categories etc. That is good, because it really deepened my understanding of the CRUD model (Create-Read-Update-Destroy).

On the minus side, it sometimes feels a bit messy and chaotic. It can therefore feel like the course has more obstacles than it needs to, but it also teaches beginners that making mistakes is a natural part of programming. If you get frustrated, remember that the time spent on this is worth it in the end.

I gave the course up at one point and tried other PHP-courses with a more "minimalistic" approch, and I simply did not learn it as efficiently. Therefore, I strongly believe this course could be the very best. I have now finished all of it, and I feel very confident that I have a working knowledge in PHP.

results.content:
I needed a refresher course on PHP, and the course has provided an excellent overview so far. The videos are kept short, which is good for aiding comprehension of the underlying principles.
The instructor's recommendation of Brackets code editor and MAMP server stack were both useful.
Good tutorials on working with a MySQL database in conjunction with PHP, especially during the building of the CMS. 
A bit too much hesitation and repetition for my taste, however, the pace might suit you if it's your first brush with PHP, and it does help to drill everything home. Although instruction seems a bit off the cuff, the resultant occasional errors, and witnessing the instructor's approach to fixing them, actually provide a good basis for learning how to tackle many of the common problems programmers run up against on a daily basis.
I would recommend this course to anyone, but it will take some patience due to the ambitious scope of the course and the slow pace; however, the scope is also what makes it worthwhile. After the many and varied usage examples, you will start to get a lot more comfortable with coding in PHP and MySQL, and will have a solid enough understanding to apply for a job as a PHP web developer.

results.content:
As more of a designer, and front ender Ive struggled for a long time trying to learn programming languages on and off, and they are just a foreign language to me. Perhaps due to lack of self confidence. For the first time, things are clear and I'm developing confidence with PHP, it actually makes sense to me. 
My favourite thing about Edwin is he lets you see the whole thing - typos and all. for me this has given me a massive boost, because i can see that even seasoned experts make mistakes and are constantly figuring things out. 
Thats why Im giving this course five stars before it's finished. - because Im further than i have been ever, from just a third of the way in. 
Thanks Edwin, I look forward to finishing the course and looking at some of the others on offer.

results.content:
It's been a long journey into this course, so, to start, thank Edwin it's been a pleasure being your student.
The course does pretty well what it says, teaching you the basic of the PHP, and something more.
I really like the big project approach, cause it feels like you're learning stuff for practical use.
As for every course, the part about variables and basic logic feels slow if u're already into development but has to be expected.
Somewhere in the middle  the course becomes a little less organized than the start (i guess cause some lecture were added later), and to understand some of the more 'complex' stuff you have to (obviously) browse the internet (especially the packages stuff) and study (which is a good pratcice).
Overall i liked both the course and the instructor (thx Edwin), and i would reccomend it to any person who wants to learn PHP.

results.content: This is a very good course that lets you build a cool portfolio project if you put in a little customization. I feel like I have a good grasp of PHP and MySQL after taking this course and can apply this knowledge on my own. However, this course wasn't originally designed to put the main project online so things can get a little messy if that's your end goal. He goes in and out of using prepared statements vs mysqli queries and doesn't keep variable naming consistent throughout the entire course.  Occasionally, I would be struggling for a long time with an issue only to find in the next lecture he would go back and fix a mistake he hadn't noticed before. I also wish he explained some of the advanced topics in more detail. Especially, if we are going to be using them in our project. All in all, it is a good course and I would recommend it.

results.content:
The course is outdated doesn't reflect the new way of writing PHP including methods for password hashing and SQL Injections. No best practises shown "you can do what you want with PHP" isn't the best thing to say to students.

He makes a lot of mistakes, spends more time troubleshooting his typos and constantly correcting himself. It appears the course was filmed on a whim, no organization. i felt like he was all over the place.

I gave up on the course at the start of the CMS, i didnt want to go any further.

response.content:
1. This course is an ever-green course, which means it never gets outdated. This course is created using CORE PHP without those extra features that get courses outdated. We also update this course with amazing functionality all the time, look at the end of the curriculum.

We show the old way of doing passwords at first cause is good to learn it because some applications still use this approach. We however learn the newer way later in the course, I wished she had waited. 

2. I do make mistakes since I believe we as teachers need to show our students how to fix errors (debug) which gives them LOT more knowledge. Because these errors is why students learned so much in the course. We fix those mistakes really fast and show many approaches to solve them.

3. There are some are some typos but not in the PHP code itself but to fill in content for examples. Lorem Ipsum is a dummy data language we use for the course.

NOTE:  Out of many reviews there is always 1 person who does not like something. When making your decision always go with the majority.

Edwin Diaz

results.content:
Through the course, I got the feeling that it was not very well thought of.  Course structure, constant mistakes, bad coding practices, no coding style.
We used this style of coding in high school/university when we didn't know how to write good, structured code.
Edwin seems like a nice guy, but please, we don't need 'Edwin from the future' when you make mistakes. Remove old video, and make a new one without mistakes. This way the course just gets longer, but useful information is getting drown in all these other, unimportant stuff.
Too much repetitive stuff (that does not need to be repeated ten times (mysql vs. mysqli for example). Or practices that we don't really know why they are done (for example, putting connection parameters in the array "for security", what security?).
So, to sum it up: if you are a complete beginner and you plan to work on some kind of your own project, this course is useful. If you want to work professionally with other people on a PHP project, I do not recommend this course.

results.content:
Having completed Edwin's JS courses. I purchased this one hoping for a similar level of quality. Unfortunately, despite the high ratings the course is simply not of an acceptable level of quality for a newcomer to php. 

There are an incredible amount of mistakes in this one, often breaking the application and a considerable amount of time is taken up going back and correcting them.

The flow of the videos is often interrupted with unnecessary distractions and diversions and little effort is made by Edwin to explain what we're doing, why and how it works. Instead this course is more of a guided tour around making an application instead of understanding php.

It's disappointing. I won't ask for a refund, as I do appreciate Edwin's efforts, especially in his other courses but this one should really be redone. 

It's painfully clear that the lectures are not planned out, which leads to a lot of stop-starting. The students should be making the mistakes not the tutor!

results.content:
The instructor is really optimistic and maintains a positive attitude throughout, but otherwise this course is in need of a revamp.

There is very little structure to the lectures, they seem to be the product of someone coding by the seat of their pants as opposed to having a clear idea of what they want their code to accomplish.

While I understand that developers of all experience levels make mistakes and there is value in learning how to debug, the code is more often than not extremely messy. This and the general lack of a clearheaded strategy lead the instructor to make any number of very basic mistakes repeatedly, and lectures become unnecessarily long as he corrects them.

Less often, but still problematic, the instructor will introduce a concept and entirely forego any attempt at an explanation (one trivial but illustrative example is when he uses the "%" symbol as part of a query for the first time).

There is no consideration given to best practices (for example the code could be significantly drier, and there is no logic to variable naming). If a developer tried to ship code in a professional environment that looks like what's taught in this course, it would result in their firing or demotion. There are a number of problems with this course and the codebase that could be avoided with the use of a linter. If nothing else, the instructor should code with syntactic and stylistic consistency, and not leave random spacing, tabs, returns, etc., everywhere.

The CMS section of the course really goes off the rails, so much so that I decided to stop progress on this course. It could be made much more valuable if students were taught how to build it from the ground up. As it stands, we're given a fairly excessive amount of code/boilerplate templates, and a number of lectures are then devoted to cutting out large sections of files, pasting them in a new file, and including them in the original. Learning how to include files is surely important concept, but walking students through the logic behind code structuring would be more helpful. The objective of many of the lectures'  seems to be to essentially reduce technical debt incurred by the starter code.

I do believe the instructor knows the language well, but has neglected to come up with a coherent way to convey his knowledge.

results.content:
While you will learn the basics of PHP, you will spend far more time being frustrated through the many many many mistakes (it seems like hours) of Edwin making a mistake, only to come back and fix it later. I guess its cool if its your own personal project, but when its other peoples time who want to know how its done right the firs time, the amount of "typing...no wait......not wait..." is unbearable for someone like myself.

I believe it provided a solid foundation in which to take to other courses lol but I didn't have the patience to suffer through the rest of this course(HOURS) and not have something I could deploy in the real world.

Thanks, but I would delete this course and redo it with user efficiency in mind.

results.content:
Excellent tutorial on PHP.  I've read about and taken other tuts on PHP, and practiced it for several years, but this course has opened my eyes to functions, encryption, refactoring, OOP, and other techniques that will make my PHP coding better and more compact.  Terrific!  

Above all, Edwin's presentation is personal: He takes time to walk you through each phase of a lesson as if he was by your side, watching you work your keyboard, he makes mistakes , then debugs them, explaining how and why all along the way.  

Better yet, his occasional 'asides' about how to face life in general aren't distractions - they're encouragement that applies on many levels. 

Looking forward to taking more E. Diaz courses . . .

results.content:
I am a pragmatist who prefers practical learning as opposed a purely theoretical one. As someone with absolutely no background in coding, searching for the right instructor with the right content was not only daunting but extremely stressful. I have tried EdX, Codecademy, and the like but they were simply not the right format for me. 

Less than a month ago, I came across this course by Edwin and finished this entire course in a month with a greater understanding of how and why PHP is used in web development. While I still have much to learn (like OOP), I’d still like to recommend this course to future students that are specifically looking for (1) A PRACTICAL application of PHP as opposed to textbook learning; (2) An ACTIVE udemy instructor that is both engaging and responsive; (3) HIGH QUALITY lectures segmented into easily consumable chunks. I know preferences for lecturing formats vary, but if you are self-disciplined and serious about learning, you should give Edwin’s course a try. Cheers!

results.content: This course teaches you basics of PHP, it's structured in a very nice way, you will be learning stuff then doing short tasks based on what you have learnt, after completing all the tasks you will begin to build a simple cms system. It gives you a little introduction to OOP programming (I wished there was little bit more of that). By the time you build the CMS, you should be able to understand how it works - It's good. The only things I would improve is to cut the amount of errors you do, and instead perhaps explain some of the other stuff in greater detail like loops, why are we using them, different situations for using specific loops, same goes with arrays.  Also, I feel like the course is lacking some API explanation and it could do with adding google maps to it and making your own app RESTful api because at some point in your programmer careers you WILL be facing APIs as well as RESTful apps. API + restful would be wonderful addition..  I've almost finished the course, I come from C# background and I must say I've learnt quite a lot and I will be making my way over to OOP PHP Course now and then ultimately Laravel - That's my plan!
results.content_html: This course teaches you basics of PHP, it's structured in a very nice way, you will be learning stuff then doing short tasks based on what you have learnt, after completing all the tasks you will begin to build a simple cms system. It gives you a little introduction to OOP programming (I wished there was little bit more of that). By the time you build the CMS, you should be able to understand how it works - It's good. The only things I would improve is to cut the amount of errors you do, and instead perhaps explain some of the other stuff in greater detail like loops, why are we using them, different situations for using specific loops, same goes with arrays. Also, I feel like the course is lacking some API explanation and it could do with adding google maps to it and making your own app RESTful api because at some point in your programmer careers you WILL be facing APIs as well as RESTful apps. I would highly recommend this course to those wanting to learn php and I will definitely be taking more of Edwins courses when I have completed this one. Thanks Edwin!

results.content:
I've currently finished 12% of the course. 

The teacher knows what he is talking about which would result in 5* but there is one downside I'm going to explain now. 

The structure of the course is well done, but the teacher did not record all videos in order which leads to countless unnecessary repeats that takes like 1-2 minutes per video (which is alot considering one video is about 6-10 minutes long). And I know, repeating is important but explaining how to do a new save as from blank.php for 10 videos in a row is a bit too much :D 
Or telling your students how to do comments in php after you just had a lesson about comments and telling them in the later video that you dont know if you already told this doesnt seem too professional.

However, if you can get over that you will get a good course :)

results.content:
The information is good, but the presentation is far too unfocused and meandering. There's too much "filler", and parts of the instruction seem to be thought up "on the fly" while the video was being recorded, rather than planned deliberately ahead of time.  //

There's too much time spent on redundant information. For example, explaining in every single video that our file lists might not look the same as yours, and why, is completely unnecessary. Besides being redundant, it also seems to indicate a lack of organization in preparing the course. If the discrepancy in file lists was concern enough to repeat the same explanation in video after video, then perhaps it would have been better to structure the lessons so that wouldn't be the case.// 

When you get into the actual topic, it's very helpful. Remove the fluff, filler and redundant explanations, and you'd have a much more concise and focused course. //

So, my rating would be 2.5 stars on the information, but -2.5 stars on the delivery/presentation.

results.content: I'm 3% of the way through the course, and had to pause and give up this course after the instructor interrupted his own thought, which was itself an interruption of another thought. We started the course with XAMPP, and in the very next video, MAMP is featured -- not that it makes much of a technical difference, but the shifting sands underneath you is very unsettling. Instructor said something in the previous lecture of "I'm pretty sure I covered this in the other lesson", regarding something that wasn't actually covered. It seems clear to me that the reason this course has so many hours of content is simply that the instructor meanders and doesn't know how to condense and organize information. Imagine trying to learn from someone with a moderate case of untreated ADHD. That's what this course feels like so far. I can only imagine that anyone who left more than a single star is rating higher than they might otherwise rate it because they want to convince themselves that they didn't just blow their money.

Steven Harrison
Arnprior, Ontario, Canada

results.content:
Good course BUT has problems.

Pros:

Very thorough in terms of having you create your very own proper application. I feel this is great way of learning a new language, by actually seeing what is possible and creating it yourself.

Great for beginners.

Lots of new lectures gets added from time to time.

Cons:

Gets very unorganized. I have a degree in Software Development and have seen lots of commercial code, but the code he writes is very unstructured, all over the place, lots of typos. This is not good for beginner as the code's maintainability really becomes difficult.

The lecturers that respond in the Q&A is not always very helpful as they only send you a link to go and read or they comment and say that your question is not in the scope of the course.

results.content:
I was initially going to give the course 2 stars but I changed my mind when I saw that any type of criticism of the instructor via comments and questions in the lecture is deleted?? Frankly it's just embarrassing and a shame, because I considered this site and the course itself to be professional, now I realize that it's just another scam like everything else. 
In the comment THAT WAS DELETED I posted that the instructor keeps making amateur mistakes, mistakes an experienced web developer would never make. Those are not syntax mistakes, it's writing unfunctional code or sometimes the code is simply wrong and unuseable. And I don't care about the fact that SOMETIMES 1, 5 or 10 lectures later there will be a video explaining a mistake was made, most of the time the mistake is simply one of an amateur and never should have been made.
Also, some of the things the instructor is teaching are not the proper way to do that specific coding. Sometimes he just overcomplicates things and makes them harder, illogical , makes the code unfunctional and unuseable, he is a lot of the time teaching the wrong way to code, harder and the mistakes he makes are those that would easily get you fired from a real job.
For example he sometimes leaves more than 1 connection to the database on one page which is completely absurd and unnecesserily  strains the computer and the server. Also, there are way to many sql queries, the proper sql syntax exists that could cut the number of queries in half and that's not even half of it! 
I gave the course and the instructor a billion chances to prove my thinking wrong and all he did is just prove me right.
Finally, and maybe THIS is just me but I don't need someone telling me at the beginning of each lecture that I should be thankful that I have both of my hands, eyes feet etc. The occasional pat on the back is ok but this is just wrong. I didn't sign up for a motivational course, I PAYED to learn php coding.

P.S. You are not building a CMS similar to wordpress, joomla etc. This is a blog you can edit at best. Wordpress and other things are not even in the same league but the course is trying to sell you that. 
Hope you don't delete this.

results.content:
To preface this review, I’m a front-end / UX developer that’s been in the industry about 5 years and though I primarily focus on the front-end, I also have experience with the backend and OOP. I bought this course as a complete PHP beginner to fulfill a business need as we migrate technologies. I have taken taken and completed a few other top-rated development courses on Udemy and as they have all been excellent and greatly valuable experiences, I chose this course because it too was a best-selling and top-rated course. Unfortunately, this course was far from what the high ratings promised and I was very dissatisfied with the time and money spent on the course, which leads me to give the "awful, not what I expected at all” rating.

My greatest issue with this course is the lack of professionalism and organization displayed by the instructor. His lectures aren’t well prepared and feel like they were recorded on a whim. For the level of experience that he professes to have, his code is riddled with many basic errors and typos which quickly becomes really distracting as a large portion of this course is him going back to troubleshoot fundamental errors. Yes, debugging comes with the territory, but the sheer amount of errors and how easily Edwin could have avoided them may make students lose confidence in his mastery of the course material. Like many other reviews have said, it would have been much easier to follow if he had rerecorded and replaced the many lectures containing the mistakes.

There is also a profound lack of best practices that would lead to poorly written code if applied on the job. There is a lot of copy and pasting, repeating large chunks of code, lack of proper indenting, a very disorganized workspace and a very strange zoom level of his code editor that makes it difficult to follow along to name a few. Following exactly as Edwin does will result in many bad habits and sloppy code.

Edwin does not give detailed explanations of his code or the PHP API and students would do better by reading the official PHP documentation to understand what’s going on and why. Contrary to the course title, this style of teaching will not lead to a mastery of PHP or set the student up for success, as he simply hands the student a proverbial fish, rather than teaching him or her how to fish. 

The course lists object oriented programming (OOP) as one of the things you will learn through the course, but it is important to mention that the course uses procedural PHP, not OOP PHP. There is a section that provides a very brief overview of OOP, which feels more like a marketing gimmick that allows Edwin to list it as something you will learn in the course. In reality it does very little to help the student understand the depth of OOP and what it can be used for as OOP is not applied on the main project: creating the CMS. There is no explanation of how procedural PHP and OOP PHP differ, why a developer would use one over the other, or which may be the modern standard. If you are looking to learn OOP PHP, contrary to what the course description may state, you will not be learning or using that in this course.

Sure, Edwin is upbeat, friendly, and seeks to motivate his students to keep going, but I personally found it off-putting, especially when more than a few lectures started with Edwin reminding his students to be grateful because "you have all of your arms and legs and still can hear and see". This type of commentary feels out of place for a development course and in the worst cases, unnecessarily extended the length of the lectures.

At the time of writing, I have completed 22 sections with a total of 205 lectures, but will be abandoning this as my primary PHP education source. To be perfectly honest, I was mislead by the amount of high reviews and would recommend any would-be students to carefully read through not only the four and five-star reviews, but also the one and two-star reviews to see if this may be right for you. In all fairness, I did learn a lot as a result of taking this course and have comfortably moved past beginner level, but most of the learning came through the official PHP documentation and other outside sources to supplement the course material. However, I am unable to recommend this course to anyone due to all the short comings of this course. As a #1 selling PHP course on Udemy, I believe the course falls far short of the standards of a top-tier and top-rated development course and ultimately fails to deliver on its promises, leaving me very disappointed.

results.content:
LISTEN UP EVERYONE! First and foremost,  I want to say Edwin Diaz is an exceptional instructor, and I have learned more from his courses than any other online courses I have taken.

I was rather skeptical at first, as I felt lost and did not know where to begin. I paid subscriptions to Team Treehouse and paid for other courses on here as well. I felt as if I was not learning very much, and I thought this was just going to be another waste of money.

I searched online, where all I was reading was sales pitches and mixed opinions that left me frustrated and more confused.

As someone who was completely inexperienced with programming, reading the documentation from PHP directly was incomprehensible to me. I needed more examples and hands on lectures to show me. I am a visual learner, so I felt this approach was more beneficial to me. 

Edwin's course guided me every little step of the way, and his teaching styles were very, very easy to understand for someone with very little to no programming knowledge. His kind, motivational attitude is very contagious and you can sense he really cares for his students. I cannot say that regarding most other instructors and lecturers. 

If I can give more than 5 stars, this man definitely deserves it.

Some advice: learn and use prepared statements and NEVER pass variables directly into a database, especially ones containing values a user inputs into a form.

Also, AFTER completing this course, learn PDO. Edwin has a great PDO course, but if you dive into the PDO course without prior knowledge of PHP, you will struggle. Same goes with OOP.

Thank you Edwin so much for helping me achieve the skills and knowledge I thought I would never be able to learn and possess! You have definitely changed my life and I am very grateful for that!

His passion for teaching and interacting with his students is like a super power.  I felt great after every lecture and looked forward to the next one.  His passion is intoxicating.

We really can't thank Edwin enough for being himself and putting the time and energy into creating this course.

You deserve this course!

results.content:
I have been working as web developer on a different platform, I will use PHP on my personal projects. The course covers general web concept.
I suggest you to cover on debugging PHP on eclipse or some IDE using some extensions like XDebug. 
Merging PHP with NoSQL databases such as MongoDB. 
Showing a scheme about what you are going to do before proceeding the course content, because when you write too much php inside your html it makes really hard to read or maintain the code that is why I also suggest separete them asap you can.
Using more complex database management tools like Mysqlworkbench which includes many complex specs like reverse-forward engineering, modaling the database and so on.

results.content:
I've barely touched the subject of PHP in the past, but I know enough HTML/CSS/JS and have enough server-related knowledge that I understand dynamic coding.

Now, while I'm early on in the course, I feel the instructor glosses over some concepts that I think help individuals compound their knowledge more. For example, the section where we're creating a "dynamic title" - the instructor fails to mention how to get that dynamic title to display on other PHP webpages. I did a little research and with my existing coding background, it was easy for me to figure out, but others might not have the same thought process. 

I may change my review later on (again, I'm still early in the course). However, this course is certainly a good introduction at a very basic level on how PHP works. I think I also got ahead of the curve because I started with a PHP & Laravel course here on Udemy, which is a tad more complicated than this. Hence, I got a little ahead of the curve. I took this so I could learn more of the basic functions such as associative arrays and control structures with PHP. Everyone's gotta start somewhere, so this isn't a bad starting point by any means!

results.content:
Instructor is overall good and a positive and friendly person, but as material goes toward more complicated topic (lecture 45 and on) sometimes he loses point and  sound confusing or he simply makes plain mistakes. He often unnecessarily changes his mind about already written code, although making those changes/improvements is not main focus of a particular course part. Or he deletes and moves already written code  or jumps from an open code file to former files fast, trying to make code there more compact. 

Code on the screen appears too large and jumping up and down while changing or cutting code along becomes quite hard to follow and act upon. Student loses point, consistency and a focus  and her confidence is diminished. I think every instructor should prepare in advance for a lesson, instead of making, uhh...ahh or hmm's or being undecided jumping around code along the way, but maybe I am wrong and this approach will force us to learn to be problem solvers. As programming is serious stuff, we need serious approach.

Still course has value so far and I do recommend it as instructor is a positive and friendly person who is willing to help us learn something. Thanks

Still a great PHP course and I will be finishing this course to it's completion.

results.content:
I make it a habit to not review courses until I work through them. I do this because I want my comments to be complete. I am only 75% of the way through this course but that is only because Edwin keeps adding extra features to improve the curriculum. It really is nice to know that once I work through the core project, there is a resource to reference and learn new techniques from in the future. 

I've learned so much in this course it is hard to remember way back to when I was learning this stuff for the first time. Not that the course is slow to get through, I just chip away at it in my limited free time. Since so many of the skills used throughout the course are explained and reinforced, I have to think back and appreciate how far Edwin has brought me in this subject. 

Edwin is a fantastic instructor. He's positive and upbeat. I listen to him on 1.25-1.5x speed so he may sound different in person but he is always excited about teaching and making sure I get the concepts down that are important. You can tell he likes to teach this stuff and I imagine that is why he is so responsive to the questions asked online. I have personally had a few questions throughout the course and he has either answered them already in response to a previous student, or taken the time to answer my questions directly.

Because of my enjoyment in this course, I have purchased other courses from Edwin to build on my knowledge. Thanks for putting in the effort for such a strong set of video lectures!

My background is finance so excel skills helped me understand some of the concepts but from a relatively novice beginning, I feel like I have come a long way. I will likely need to review the course again before I call myself a PHP developer but I'm glad to have an awesome CMS that I can use as a backbone in the future. I feel like I have enough baseline skills to build an application that I can continue to develop over time.

Thanks Edwin,

 - Kyle (Oakland, CA)

results.content:
Edwin is a great teacher, however at times he seems to ramble on and you get a little lost. 

However saying this, his method of teaching is laid back and explained in laymen terms which help better understand what we are doing any why. 

After the core PHP Elements have been taught it was well enough to cover a majority of his lessons without actually needing to what what he was doing. 

From this course I now have a better understanding of how Websites are formatted and brought together using PHP. 

I recommend this course to anyone wanting to learn PHP. I have purchased other courses done by Edwin and I'm looking forward to completing them. 

The only reason that I have not given this 5 starts is that some sections are badly done providing little to no explanation due to him having that particular section as part of another course. Ideally if I purchase a course I want to have the course content focused on that course and not other aspects from another. I felt that at times he could have provided more in-depth explanations and go more in depth on the areas that this course covers.

results.content: So first of all I'd like to say that if you are here to learn PHP it's absolutely the best course teaching it on Udemy. Whole CMS project covers so many topics that I didn't even think of. This course will teach you everything you need to become a PHP dev. However there are some thing I'd work at on Edwin's place. The first thing I would change is to better organize the course, all lessons aren't that well arranged, Edwin's using different code editor every 4-5 lessons, and even though it's not stopping you from learning sometimes it's really distracting, also because there are so many EXTRA features added as the time goes by often he has code that we didn't even work on. What I've seen in different courses it's that people just attach their code on every lesson, and it's easier that way to follow up. And as for second thing I'd change, and maybe it's not that important, but I found it a bit annoying is that there are too much blank spaces in code. I mean I know that's something everyone is doing their way, but it's really making it harder to read your code sometimes. Anyways I don't want to be harsh or anything, I really appreciate this course and I think that's really the best one out there, hope my "constructive criticism" was the most "constructive" it could be, have a great day and if I'll ever need to learn something else about PHP I'll certainly come back. :)

Anyways I don't want to be harsh or anything, I really appreciate this course and I think that's really the best one out there, hope my "constructive criticism" was the most "constructive" it could be, have a great day and if I'll ever need to learn something else about PHP I'll certainly come back. :)

results.content: Instructor makes a lot of errors and toggles rapidly between screens (I have to look at the top to see what screen he is on as he jumps in split seconds, so I pause frequently) so the student cannot follow. I soemetimes have to go frame-by-frame with video playback to (hopefully) see what he is up to. Also, he misses some details which I need to figure out on my own. Code that was never there in the first place suddenly appears in subsequent chapters. That is bad. There is also no code sheet in between lessons to see where I went wrong or what we are missing. Instructor does not use clear, concise language to explain what he is doing. For example, when he says, 'we are going to take out this code', does he mean 'delete' or 'cut' the code snippet? Poor language usage. It is not that he cannot speak English, it is that he does not use language simply, clearly and effectively when teaching. The spelling errors I can handle, but not his confusion and carelessness. He even misses errors in his code. One moment he will work on a piece of code, then rapidly abandon it. I am in the most important chapter, 'how to use databases' and it is a nightmare. I had to go through it twice. I want to grab him by the shirt and yell, "SLOW THE F*** DOWN AND THINK FIRST! MAKE UP YOUR MIND!! WHAT IS IT THAT YOU WANT TO DO? OKAY, STEP BY STEP!" I have tried to reach the instructor for a while, but he does not respond. The instructor needs to do this course again and go step-by-step and explain in clear, concise language (and not mumble) what he is doing and why. He must go slowly and logically and methodically, not like a confused, groggy bumblebee. The instructor is young and knows his stuff, he just needs to teach what he knows clearly, logically and in a pragmatic way. Maybe he is better in subsequent chapters, but this one is more punishment than learning. He gives aspirin a headache (in this chapter) and I dread the experience. Also, really important, when the code pages get longer, he does not shrink the screen to give context and show, 'this is what I am doing, see?'. We are left to struggle to find out, 'okay, where on the page is he making the changes?' hit pause, because he will be on another screen without warning. The first time doing the lesson, I was making changes to the wrong screen because I did not see him toggle. My advice to the instructor, 'stop, think, plan, execute'. Also, look up a guy called 'John Mighton' and JUMP. Mighton goes over one method of teaching that works. Edwin Diaz does not need to do longer videos, just smarter, more coherent ones, and provide chapter sample codes so we all can follow. This is not the place for you to figure out stuff, Mr. Diaz, but for you to guide us firmly and clearly.

Only minor quibbles so far:

1. Constantly repeating 'if your structure looks different, don't worry about it.' We get it. No need to repeat every video for 10 videos.

2. A little more time taken to spell things correctly - or at least not misspell it 15 times in a row.

All in all, it's a VERY informative course, and I haven't seen one any better, but perfection is a constant battle. As close to perfect as one can reasonably expect.

Kudos!

results.content:
PHP code in course, in regards to the actual CMS application, has already been changed to reflect future courses. Lectures are using different PHP code, DBs in the actual code aren't set up yet so things don't work as in the lectures. This starts somewhere around lecture 80, or whatever lecture begins the actual CMS application part of the course. This makes it very difficult to follow the lectures.

Don't insert 'future' into the 'past'. Doing that means the code no longer reflects the lectures.

I was enjoying this course up until the CMS application lecture started. Now, it is just too difficult to follow, so I won't be continuing.

Great hands-on course. Some explanations could be clearer rather than simply pointing to google. Even one sentence explanations work.
For example, if you are trying to refresh the page using header command from within an include that is after the header include, you either need to create a new page or use ob_start() function else PHP gives you a warning. Such items can be explicitly explained.

results.content:
Decent quality, but long-winded, some explanations could be shortened and Edwin can sometimes take a while to get to the point. Overall Edwin is an interesting and great tutor, my main reason for only giving 4.5 stars is that following along exactly may pick up some bad habits in terms of structure etc... when it comes to writing a secure application. 

Overall a worthwhile course for beginners, but if you are looking for a quick refresher, or some practice project ideas it is not the ideal course. 

Give the course a try, it may be just what you are looking for! I have still found it a worthwhile project.

results.content:
I write this review as a professional educator.  I hate leaving bad reviews, but this course was maddening.  There's no doubt that Edwin knows PHP, but his lack of lesson organization and attention to detail turns what could have been a well-executed lesson plan into a cacophony of confused errors and incorrect code.

There isn't a video that I could find in the entire 30-hour series in which Edwin doesn't make at least one coding error.  He repeatedly states that making errors is part of the learning process.  Sure, that's true when students are practicing on their own, but not when a teacher is attempting to provide instruction in a new topic.  

Can you imagine sitting in math class, and every day your math teacher writes incorrect equations on the board, doesn't notice his errors until later, and then quickly closes up the lesson?  Can you imagine if that happened every single day?  Would you continue to go to that math class, if you had the choice?

In addition, Edwin repeatedly self-references how great of a teacher he thinks that he is (asking, "I'm a great teacher, right?").  While some may find that endearing, I found it frustrating, considering that he makes so many coding mistakes in each video.

Third, Edwin is continuously - and I mean continuously - making typing errors, nearly every single line.  I understand that not everyone is a great typist, but that is what video-editing software and re-shoots are for.

Fourth, Edwin's lack of lesson preparedness and organization means that he frequently makes mistakes, then inserts "Edwin from the future" videos noting past mistakes, THEN jumps back to what I assume are original course videos where the same coding mistakes are still present.  Again, this is entirely due to laziness on the teacher's part (not wanting to re-shoot the lesson with the errors), rather than what's best for a student looking to learn.

I wish that someone had pointed out the above before I purchased this course.  For those same reasons, I cannot in good faith recommend this course to anyone looking to learn PHP in any semblance of an organized and thoughtful manner.
results.content_html:
I write this review as a professional educator. I hate leaving bad reviews, but this course was maddening. There's no doubt that Edwin knows PHP, but his lack of lesson organization and attention to detail turns what could have been a well-executed lesson plan into a cacophony of confused errors and incorrect code.

There isn't a video that I could find in the entire 30-hour series in which Edwin doesn't make at least one coding error. He repeatedly states that making errors is part of the learning process. Sure, that's true when students are practicing on their own, but not when a teacher is attempting to provide instruction in a new topic.

Can you imagine sitting in math class, and every day your math teacher writes incorrect equations on the board, doesn't notice his errors until later, and then quickly closes up the lesson? Can you imagine if that happened every single day? Would you continue to go to that math class, if you had the choice?

In addition, Edwin repeatedly self-references how great of a teacher he thinks that he is (asking, "I'm a great teacher, right?"). While some may find that endearing, I found it frustrating, considering that he makes so many coding mistakes in each video.

Third, Edwin is continuously - and I mean continuously - making typing errors, nearly every single line. I understand that not everyone is a great typist, but that is what video-editing software and re-shoots are for.

Fourth, Edwin's lack of lesson preparedness and organization means that he frequently makes mistakes, then inserts "Edwin from the future" videos noting past mistakes, THEN jumps back to what I assume are original course videos where the same coding mistakes are still present. Again, this is entirely due to laziness on the teacher's part (not wanting to re-shoot the lesson with the errors), rather than what's best for a student looking to learn.

I wish that someone had pointed out the above before I purchased this course. For those same reasons, I cannot in good faith recommend this course to anyone looking to learn PHP in any semblance of an organized and thoughtful manner.

results.content:
All basic Topics of PHP are covered in this Course. The CMS Project is pretty good, too... especially because of the added Features in the newer Sections.

Why 1.5 Stars deduction? Because some parts of the "Beginner-Sections" need more explanation (for real Beginners).
Also, too much and very fast scrolling (back and forth).. which confuses a lot!
In addition, this course has just one Section regarding object oriented PHP. In my opinion, nowadays the focus should be on OOP. The CMS Project is completely procedural, which isn't bad (it's always hard to keep a Course up to date ;) )
All in all, a good course for real Beginners of PHP. All basic topics are covered, including a great project!
