results.content:
I started taking Edwin's course because I have an upcoming internship as a backend PHP developer coming up as part of my AP degree in Computer Science. Since PHP is not a language we ever touched on in school, this seemed like a good place to start. After 3 weeks I'm currently 70% through the course and so far I really feel like the course is delivering everything that I've expected.

Pros:
- Edwin is energetic, motivating and honestly made me wanna study a little more on days when I didn't feel like it.
- You quickly get hands on experience and practice with PHP in a web environment and the CMS project enforces your understanding about everything you do.
- The lectures are short and, mostly, straight to the point which keeps you engaged and actively learning, instead of listening to theory and instructions for 10 minutes before doing any coding.
- First part of the course, which teaches you the fundamentals, has exercises which forces you to take a step back and evaluate what you've learned and try it out again. This helps a lot!
- Edwin keeps adding new things to the course, corrects outdated lectures and is actively engaged in conversation and feedback with his students in the Q&A section.
- The course also contains a few lectures on JS, JQuery and Bootstrap which is a nice little bonus on top of everything else.

Cons:
- The course has a bit too many videos about editing existing HTML templates downloaded from the course ressource files, particularly in the beginning. This does get quite boring and makes you wonder why those edits weren't made beforehand.
- There is A LOT of copying of existing logic in this course, particularly in the CMS project, which does lead to bloat and makes your overview of the project difficult towards the end. While I do understand the procedural approach of the course, it does seem strange to have lectures about modularising and condensing code into functions only to then kind of forgetting about it.
- Some videos and explanations still needs updating despite Edwin revisiting regularly. Nothing too annoying or off putting though.

Overall I find this course very good and would recommend it to anyone wanting to learn PHP. I honestly do feel a lot more ready for my upcoming internship and am excited to finish the rest of the course. I will update this review should any of my opinions change after I've finished the rest. Thanks Edwin!
results.content_html:
I started taking Edwin's course because I have an upcoming internship as a backend PHP developer coming up as part of my AP degree in Computer Science. Since PHP is not a language we ever touched on in school, this seemed like a good place to start. After 3 weeks I'm currently 70% through the course and so far I really feel like the course is delivering everything that I've expected.

Pros:
- Edwin is energetic, motivating and honestly made me wanna study a little more on days when I didn't feel like it.
- You quickly get hands on experience and practice with PHP in a web environment and the CMS project enforces your understanding about everything you do.
- The lectures are short and, mostly, straight to the point which keeps you engaged and actively learning, instead of listening to theory and instructions for 10 minutes before doing any coding.
- First part of the course, which teaches you the fundamentals, has exercises which forces you to take a step back and evaluate what you've learned and try it out again. This helps a lot!
- Edwin keeps adding new things to the course, corrects outdated lectures and is actively engaged in conversation and feedback with his students in the Q&A section.
- The course also contains a few lectures on JS, JQuery and Bootstrap which is a nice little bonus on top of everything else.

Cons:
- The course has a bit too many videos about editing existing HTML templates downloaded from the course ressource files, particularly in the beginning. This does get quite boring and makes you wonder why those edits weren't made beforehand.
- There is A LOT of copying of existing logic in this course, particularly in the CMS project, which does lead to bloat and makes your overview of the project difficult towards the end. While I do understand the procedural approach of the course, it does seem strange to have lectures about modularising and condensing code into functions only to then kind of forgetting about it.
- Some videos and explanations still needs updating despite Edwin revisiting regularly. Nothing too annoying or off putting though.

Overall I find this course very good and would recommend it to anyone wanting to learn PHP. I honestly do feel a lot more ready for my upcoming internship and am excited to finish the rest of the course. I will update this review should any of my opinions change after I've finished the rest. Thanks Edwin!

results.content:
I'm an experienced programmer of many years but never took the time to learn PHP. Well circumstances changed and I needed to learn PHP but all I could find are classes for newbies. You see, I knew programming logic and data flow and all those things that are expected from a veteran developer. I just needed to learn the PHP language.

Then I found Edwin Diaz's courses on Udemy.

This course is clear, concise and is perfect for newbies but also for experienced developers. It taught me the syntax of PHP (the hard part) and then showed how that syntax is applied. For an experienced developer, that was perfect. 

The brief lessons are to the point and easy to understand but still thorough and surprisingly in-depth. They seem so simple. 

I promise you, it's not the last course I expect to take from Edwin. Love this guy!

Yep, it's five stars from me.

results.content:
Difficulty using Updated version of Xampp for Mac OSX 10.12.5 Sierra.
Solved (so far):

Default local host is actually - "localhost:8080"

Navigate to Volumes tab in XAMPP, click "Mount", then click "Explore" this will show the htdocs folder that is referenced in the first lecture. Drag your renamed demo folder into the dashboard sub-folder.

localhost address = "http://localhost:8080/dashboard/demo2/"
results.content_html:
Difficulty using Updated version of Xampp for Mac OSX 10.12.5 Sierra.
Solved (so far):

Default local host is actually - "localhost:8080"

Navigate to Volumes tab in XAMPP, click "Mount", then click "Explore" this will show the htdocs folder that is referenced in the first lecture. Drag your renamed demo folder into the dashboard sub-folder.

localhost address = "http://localhost:8080/dashboard/demo2/"

results.content:
As a total beginner, I would say that I did learn a fairly good amount and that I was able to get to know PHP and SQL's basic functions. In addition to this, the instructor and his team are very responsive whenever you ask a question.

However, I wouldn't say I became a PHP master. There were a lot of times wherein I felt lost because certain functions and how they worked were not explained well enough. Lastly, I would say that the course lacks structure. We would be jumping from one thing to another rather quickly, and sometimes, certain lines of code would either appear or disappear from the files that the instructor is working on, making it hard to follow or understand where things went or came from.

Despite the challenges you may face in trying to understand what's going on, I think this course is a good starting point for people who want to get into PHP nonetheless. It gives you a general idea of it's important features and how to apply them. It would be up to you, however, to take yourself to the next level.

We would be jumping from one thing to another rather quickly, and sometimes, certain lines of code would either appear or disappear from the files that the instructor is working on, making it hard to follow or understand where things went or came from.

Despite the challenges you may face in trying to understand what's going on, I think this course is a good starting point for people who want to get into PHP nonetheless. It gives you a general idea of it's important features and how to apply them. It would be up to you, however, to take yourself to the next level.

results.content:
Honestly, this course is just to good to be true! It is actually an understatement to say that I have problems finding the right types of words, just because the fact that what Edwin does, he does really, really well! 

By my opinion this is probably one of the best courses you could ever get! (And possibly the best PHP course ever made - and no, I was not paid for my review!) This course is huge and gives you TONS of knowledge, resources, tips and tricks for just about $10 - $20 US.. All this and you can keep it for a lifetime! 

Without any doubt, Edwin is an outstanding teacher and his knowledge base is huge. His skills set is clearly reflecting the fact that he masters several programming languages and has a lot of experience. And I still have yet to see any of my questions in Q's&A's unanswered within 2 hours.

Last but maybe the most important thing is the fact that Edwin is really fun to listen to. How he commits into the role and try his best to teach us smart and clever ways of writing PHP. I would say that this course really is unique & special.  What most other teachers out there couldn't do - Edwin makes it actually interesting and fun. 

Without further ado, this is one of the most demanding and highest rated courses on Udemy. I don't think there is much left to say...

results.content: Edwin is personable, engaging, fun, and his enthusiasm is infectious. I like that he encourages his students, and shows us that mistakes aren't bad, as they help us better understand what we are learning and how to search for solutions.  He also seemed to know just when I needed to go get a cup of coffee! ;)  The course is fantastic, and really goes into the practical uses of PHP for any beginner to intermediate user.  I already have a degree in web design and development, so this course was a great way to refresh what I knew and develop my skills more.  I liked that his lectures were short, so that I could do one, or a few, at a time, to fit them within my schedule.  Thank you so much, Edwin!  I look forward to added lectures. :)

results.content: Very good course. I think some stuff could be improved, but those are just details. If I had known about Udemy before, I would have saved money, time and pulling my hair out lots of times by not going to school for web development where, even if I learnt some serious stuff and I have a nice official diploma (silly formality to apply for some companies), this specifical course is way much much more practical and I have learnt more and in less time (done in 3 weeks) than in the 2nd school trimester where I just badly learnt a stupid login and register on php, (besides studying online I am able to learn in my undies at home :) haha). Also I have kind of impostor syndrome and I was scared (still am) of applying to jobs after finishing school but I think after the OOP course and then the PDO one, I will have more trust in myself and I will be able to get some nice job. Nice teacher, very fun even if sometimes he is a bit "tale-teller" (my course is awesome, you will become rich with this, bla bla bla) but I guess most of these teachers online are like this so they motivate the students but at the end, he takes a smile from your face and cheers up your day a little bit. Kuddos and... with that name you have, don't you speak some spanish? ;)

results.content:
tl;dr: A very informative course, well-paced, great techniques to implement in active projects.

The deets:  Been learning PHP in a very much a trial-and-error method (which I highly do not recommend to anyone looking into the language, please take a course instead).  I was having trouble tackling a certain project and decided to learn from the ground up, figuring it might help me overcome the wall I'd hit with the database.  Within a few hours of this course, I'd debugged my current code from its very unfortunate novice errors thanks to what I'd be learning!  

I've very much enjoyed both the pace set by this course and the methods used to teach.  The hands-on, work-as-you-go method is the best for me to learn and the instructor speaks in a very pleasant manor that is eloquent enough to speak to his knowledge but casual enough that it doesn't get tuned out because it is too "rigid".  There are a multitude of projects added on to the course to learn and I am very excited to go through all of them at length to develop projects I've been wanting to do.

Drop another star. This is horrible to watch. No proper indentations and the coding style is not consistent. There are other editors which can help you to format the code properly. VS Code even has the "format on save" feature. Beginners, there are many PHP coding standards you can Google search. for example, https://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/best-practices/coding-standards/php/

I can guarantee that the coding style in these course videos won't pass code review if you want to work in FAANG.

Edwin I came across you after hours and hours of digging around on the internet. Through your youtube channel I've learned so much about responsive design. 
To "EVERYONE" else the instructor knows his stuff and teaches step by step how to do simple things and gradually introduces us to ways we can use what we learned in our own webpages. 
You'll also learn how to troubleshoot and to fix common issues if you are a new to php and already have some experience you'll definetly be able to start working with php immediately.
Aside from the extremly well laid out coarse the best benefit of this coarse isn't how quick you'll pick up on, it's getting the answers to the questions you have and the level of engagement from the instructor and the rest of the community!

results.content:
The course starts as a great introduction to PHP and programming in general. The project is perfect for a beginner and Edwin has a great way of approaching the daunting task of learning programming.
However, about one third through the course, the learning stops and becomes a pure code-along with repetitive code and technical copy-paste sessions. There is some very valuable information at the end of the course.
All in all, the instructor is delivering some valuable content, but instead of going back and enriching old lectures, they just add "stuff" at the end without keeping any coherence to the course.

results.content: This course while pretty good, I find an in depth knowledge as to why the code is doing what it is doing very lacking. I feel this course will not make a PHP master as it is a very brief overview of PHP. The positive thing about this course is the instructor does update his course and fixes some mistakes. There is some bad programming practices this instructor uses such as not commenting code to explain what a section is doing. In my opinion, is it worth the time and money, I would say if you can get it at a discount it would be worth it but at the time of this review the $200 price tag would be inadvisable as there are books and free courses that will give you a more through understanding. I am not a PHP expert however I am a software programmer and backend web developer using other languages as my 20+ years of experience.

results.content: For the past year or so, I've tried all sorts of sites that offer JavaScript & PHP courses, many of which were quite expensive, usually around $25-$50 a month. I stumbled upon Edwin's courses about 2 or 3 months ago, and I can say without a doubt that these courses are the best possible way to learn PHP. The other subscription-based services were great for about a week, until I got incredibly bored with the material. But with this course (and Edwin's other courses), I'm never bored and I've been learning a lot more. The courses are definitely worth the money.
results.content_html: For the past year or so, I've tried all sorts of sites that offer JavaScript & PHP courses, many of which were quite expensive, usually around $25-$50 a month. I stumbled upon Edwin's courses about 2 or 3 months ago, and I can say without a doubt that these courses are the best possible way to learn PHP. The other subscription-based services were great for about a week, until I got incredibly bored with the material. results.content: There is absolutely no reason why anyone serious about becoming a web developer should not take this course. This course has taught me learn to build a custom CMS for my first client as a freelancer. Other "everything-you-need-know" PHP courses pale in comparison to Edwin's. Most of them lack applicability for large size projects. No other PHP course I've taken so far has spent this much time applying the knowledge, and even if they did, they were really really simple applications. This CMS is no simple application, nor is it a simple demonstration. This is a months-long project that constantly reinforces PHP knowledge (and gives great exposure to SQL). I am actually sad that I've almost reached the end of this course. No worries, though--I am enrolled in Edwin's OOP PHP and Ecommerce course, which would no doubt be stellar as well.

results.content:
I recommend this to everyone who wants to learn PHP
The project we create in this course is literally worth $5000. And the skills you learn during the course are worth even more!

I was going to give this course 4 stars, but I changed my mind closer to the end. Yes, Edwin's code can be inconsistent at times and there is a lot of jumping around here and there. But this is what makes it so much better. I would get one bug and it would take me almost a whole day get rid of the bug. But this is exactly how real life scenarios are. Dealing with bugs and asking questions is what make you a better developer!
Bugs are challenges. If you stay precisely on course, there will only be a few bugs every now and then.

PHP is a powerful tool and I'm really glad I learned it! Helps me to think of a lot more projects! Most of my projects seemed impossible to write, but now with the skills I learned in this course, I can easily think of code for some of the problems I encountered!

Thanks again guys!

results.content:
First of all Edwin is a great teacher: He has a friendly character, is very motivating and he really knows what is takes you to really start learning this stuff. I like and appreciate Edwin as a teacher and this is one star worth.

Now to this course: This course is 6 years old and outdated: It does not show best practices from today! Yes, Edwin adds "Edwin from the future"-Videos every time something really important changes and yes je uses valid code such as mysqli and it is important you know about its existence.

But that's not best practice anymore for several years already! Today pdo is the recommended way for database communication. Plus: It is time consuming to make things the old way just to change it to some newer stuff in the next video.

Udemy sadly encourages teacher to update old courses into oblivion instead of encouraging them to make a newer up to date best practices version. On Udemy it is more important to teachers to have hundreds of sales on their course to sell more and Udemy itself hides well WHEN a course was LAUNCHED... just telling the buyer when it was updated. This is a big problem for all Udemys tech courses... more than half the web technology courses I visited so far are kind of outdated and therefore I almost stopped completely to buy them! Web techniques change so fast and after about 2 years best practices are totally different.

This course could be really great with a a complete makeover where all the "newer" (already years old by now) future Edwins would be packed into the regular stream of information.
I wrote Edwin this 2 weeks ago in private and not just put it here as a complaint. Though he always responded to my questions about course topics, he did not answer this - seems he does not want to hear about his course being outdated.

This is how I wanted to learn php: I started programming in october 2018 with this course. And I understood the basics well enough. But I missed smaller exercises to train the basics. I did not make the step to start following along the cms... cause I felt I need more basics exercise. I bought another course with 24+ small exercises from another teacher here on Udemy and learned basic procedural php really well there.

Beginn of this year I came back to go ahead with Edwins cms. But meanwhile I learned some things and suddenly this course seems outdated of best practices. Plus: programming a cms procedural might train you php... but you are never going to use it. Procedural is hard to maintenance and hard to bugfix. I am not going to invested the time to program something in so many hours I am not going to use.

I switched to Edwins OOP - building a photo gallery course instead. I bought it together with this one and there again: msqli instead of pdo - outdated! In the questions and answers several students asked him to add pdo... Edwin answered he thought it to be too difficult for his students BUT still he said to put it on his todo list... those posts are about 4 month old! Meanwhile he asked what course to do next, but did not add pdo to this course.

PDO might be a bit more complex compared to msqli but it makes database communication way saver! My guess is, pdo is not too difficult for us to learn but for Edwin to adapt his courses to.

I finished 25% of this course - all basics and several cms videos. I stopped then cause my time is too valuable to spend it on outdated stuff. I am really disappointed about this course and cannot recommend it. This courses cms is just a selling point for newbies: noone needs a procedural php cms anyway!

From today point of view this and the OOP course was a total waste of money and time.

I learned OOP from another teacher as well - he uses best practices such as pdo and as well design patterns such as Model View Controller (MVC). This is the modern stuff you really need to know. Sadly for most ppl is that this course is only available in German. Thanks to Udemy not encouraging new courses on well published topics there seems to be a big lag about modern php.
Meanwhile I advanced to the php framework Laravel. I am busy rebuilding my 15 years old really big web application with oop php, best practice design patterns and a a modern framework on my own - all learned outside this course. I am as well not buying any other courses from Edwin, fearing those might be outdated as well.
Though I do not want to deny... my very first steps in php I made here and had quite some fun with it! Plus Edwin gave me the confidence that I will be able to learn php. My big thanks for this!

I am sorry to give Edwin a bad review. And I am sorry for him that he sticks to what he has so hard instead of taking his experience as a teacher with all those questions he got and answered in his course and make a splendid new course. With investing a bit of his time and experience he could be saving hundreds of hour of lifetime for his students and teach them all the up to date stuff. And I am sure he will make good money out of a new course.

He is a good teacher and I surely knows all the good new stuff!
results.content_html:
First of all Edwin is a great teacher: He has a friendly character, is very motivating and he really knows what is takes you to really start learning this stuff. I like and appreciate Edwin as a teacher and this is one star worth.

Now to this course: This course is 6 years old and outdated: It does not show best practices from today! Yes, Edwin adds "Edwin from the future"-Videos every time something really important changes and yes je uses valid code such as mysqli and it is important you know about its existence.

But that's not best practice anymore for several years already! Today pdo is the recommended way for database communication. Plus: It is time consuming to make things the old way just to change it to some newer stuff in the next video.

Udemy sadly encourages teacher to update old courses into oblivion instead of encouraging them to make a newer up to date best practices version. On Udemy it is more important to teachers to have hundreds of sales on their course to sell more and Udemy itself hides well WHEN a course was LAUNCHED... just telling the buyer when it was updated. This is a big problem for all Udemys tech courses... more than half the web technology courses I visited so far are kind of outdated and therefore I almost stopped completely to buy them! Web techniques change so fast and after about 2 years best practices are totally different.

This course could be really great with a a complete makeover where all the "newer" (already years old by now) future Edwins would be packed into the regular stream of information.
I wrote Edwin this 2 weeks ago in private and not just put it here as a complaint. Though he always responded to my questions about course topics, he did not answer this - seems he does not want to hear about his course being outdated.

results.content:
Standard MySQL tutorials should be all using the PDO object model.
The security discussion to eliminate injection is pathetic. The function of escape strings is deprecated in mysql and the example shown isn't a real-world injection....password security is a serious affair and taught properly can be a great launchpad into understanding security for a site.  This is important to get right and using mycrypt is not the standard today at all!  Very disappointed so far.

results.content:
Got blocked immediately and had to figure out the basics of the XAMPP (Mac) installation myself. You're not walked through it, so I got stuck immediately and had to go googling to resolve it on my own. It turned out to be a few simple steps that you have to do when you start XAMPP, and it would have taken him very little time to go over them in a useful way, but that was simply neglected in the course. For a "beginner" course, to get blocked so quickly is disappointing. I'm going to keep going with the course and see how it goes, but it doesn't bode well that it already skims over details in the first module.
[...]
Immediately starts using software he hasn't had us install or explained anything about. ("If you're going to be using MAMP, just [do this, do that, do...]"  Wait... what the eff is MAMP?) Seeking a refund in favour a better-explained course.

results.content:
This is a long class, but it's well worth the time and effort. You start out by learning the basics and then go on to build an entire content management system. When you complete this class you WILL know PHP.

I have taken a couple of PHP classes before, and I could follow along with the lectures and build something that worked but I never really understood how it worked, why it worked, or what I was doing. While taking this class though it all finally "clicked". I get it now, and I am very comfortable going on and building my own projects in PHP.

Edwin has a knack for explaining a complicated concept in a way that is very easy to understand, and he has become one of my favorite instructors on Udemy. His personality and teaching style make the class fun and entertaining as well as informative. I have also taken Edwin's Javascript and jQuey classes and those are also excellent.

If you want to learn PHP, even if you've struggled with it in the past, I can't recommend this class highly enough.

results.content:
This is a really great course with a lot of detail. It is very well structured, and building a CMS is a great way to learn PHP  for wordpress, as it gives an idea of what must be happening behind the scenes. It seems to really go through the bulk of PHP function in a way that seems useful and interesting.
I would only say that sometimes the teacher ums and aahs and changes his mind as he is going, so it can seem like he should have put in a little more planning to some of the lectures. And other times he scans up and down on the screen, and its hard to keep track of exactly what he is doing.
Still, I'm really pleased with how much I am learning, and really enjoying the course. Its a bit addictive, and hard to stop sometimes!
I definitely recommend this course.

results.content: I have completed the main part of this course and it is awesome. As a practical exercise I have followed Edwin (the course tutor) to develop an amazing CMS system. It is easy to see how this could have a range of practical applications and how skills learnt can be profitably deployed. Edwin has an engaging and charismatic style and guides the student through steps which can be complicated with precision and clarity.

results.content:
I started this course as I needed to learn PHP for my new job. It's a procedural PHP course as opposed to OOP, but I have already signed up for the instructors OOP/CodeIgniter course, which is going to be more relevant in the job.
However, it's a very good course, and the instructor is fantastic. I can honestly say that i have really enjoyed it. The pace can be quite quick at times, and as a beginner you'll find you will have to rewatch a number of the videos, to get things working correctly, but for me this was fine. The QA section is really useful as well, as the chances are someone else has already encountered similar problems.
Overall, I would say the course is really worthwhile doing, and for anyone wanting to learn about PHP, I would highly recommend it.
results.content_html:

results.content:
Edwin is an amazing instructor with a very endearing personality. You can tell that he really wants his students to learn the material, and he does everything in his power to ensure this happens. 

I have completed the first four sections of the course so far and I am very pleased with the depth, pace, and quality of all the lessons. At this point, I can say with confidence that by the end of this course I will have a strong working understanding of PHP!

Thanks Edwin!!!

results.content:
I didn't watched all the course yet, but so far I have lot of things that I really don't like, the most annoying thing is that in almost every video we waste a couple of minutes looking for the instructor looking for something missing like a missing comma or a not closed tag or even creating a file with no extension.


This course says it is intended for all levels, but I think it should be designed for beginners only, and the sad part is that if you start learning with this course you will learn with bad practices and lack of standards.


I hope I could learn something new till the end of course.
